context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You are limiting the -- the "any other provision of law" to any other provision of law specified in the charging -- in the counts of conviction, correct?

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: --That is the -- yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: We are recognizing that limitation.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So you -- you said to Justice Alito that you weren't reading anything in, but you are.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You are reading into it that the other provision of law to refer to counts of conviction at sentencing, correct?

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So why is that read-in logical, meaning it's giving no extra punishment for the possession of a firearm?

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: Your Honor, two things--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Which is, I think, Justice Ginsburg's.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I think you weren't finished answering my question.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: And Justice Sotomayor, to return to your question, -- if I could answer it in two parts.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: First -- and I didn't mean to overstate, if I did -- we are not reading additional language into it.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: Our reading is contained within the context and the actual text that -- that is confined to section 924(c).

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Explain how, because you just said to Justice Scalia that if the mandatory minimum is in a separate charging instrument, then it doesn't affect you at all.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It only affects you if the count is in a count of conviction at sentencing.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: But we maintain that this is the most natural reading.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: And in fact, for instance, when this concern came up in Deal, that was confirmed the most natural reading of the plain text.

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: The Government would actually turn that analysis on its head under these circumstances.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Breyer is reading a bit what your co-counsel is advocating, what Mr. Abbott is arguing?

context.speaker: David L. Horan
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: And it is a shift not just to a guidelines regime, because if this a major policy shift into a different world, there -- it poses a question of statutory construction as well, not just about guidelines.

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: And that's the next topic, which is--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, wait.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, the guidelines can't be, as Justice Breyer said, just like a mandatory.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: They can't be, can they?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I did.

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: There will be a free-floating adjudication of guilt.

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: And because the defendant, let's say, is a felon in possession and is sentenced under the Armed Career Criminal Act, when the judge goes to sentencing, the judge, on Petitioner's view, says: I will give you 15 years under the Armed Career Criminal Act; that triggers the except clause, and therefore, I impose no sentence whatsoever under section 924(c).

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: That also is an anomaly.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: As Justice Breyer has pointed out, he can take that into account in figuring out what sentence he would want to impose beyond the greater minimum.

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: That is true.

context.speaker: Roy W. McLeese, III
context.text: My point about the anomaly is just that it is very strange, to my knowledge unheard of, to have a judge go to sentencing and have a series of adjudications and to tell the judge as to one of them that it's not the greater or lesser included offense of another; you don't even need to impose a sentence on that adjudication.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And dispositive here, the defendant is not spared from serving a discrete 924(c) sentence by virtue of receiving a higher mandatory minimum on a different count of conviction in Abbott's case, being a felon in possession of a firearm and in Gould's, drug trafficking.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Rather a 924(c) violator is subject to the highest mandatory minimum specified for the conduct offending 924(c) unless another provision of law addressed to the conduct prescribed by 924(c), imposes an even greater mandatory minimum.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Our decision is unanimous.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.

American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.speaker: Justice Roberts
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.case_name: American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Connecticut
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: We think that prudential standing best reflects the Court's general intuition in this area that when a problem is of this magnitude and literally involving the world, where everyone is a potential perpetrator, everyone is a potential victim, and where their own theory at page 15 of their brief and 32 and 40 states:

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: "If someone contributes one drop to the nuisance, they can be sued. "

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Counsel, you don't usually -- your phrase is exactly what bothers me.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We don't usually base a decision on our general intuition, and the idea of prudential standing that we have jurisdiction of the case but we're not going to decide it is contrary to Chief Justice Marshall's famous line that if we don't have jurisdiction, we can't decide it, but if we do, we have to decide it.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: But I think that the prudential standing doctrine generally and the zone of interest test in particular really do focus on this question, Mr. Chief Justice, about whether or not a case can be cut down to judicially manageable standards.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'll give that you on the zone of interests, but there you're dealing with administrative law and a very narrow proposition.

American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.speaker: Justice Roberts
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.case_name: American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Connecticut
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We don't usually base a decision on our general intuition, and the idea of prudential standing that we have jurisdiction of the case but we're not going to decide it is contrary to Chief Justice Marshall's famous line that if we don't have jurisdiction, we can't decide it, but if we do, we have to decide it.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: But I think that the prudential standing doctrine generally and the zone of interest test in particular really do focus on this question, Mr. Chief Justice, about whether or not a case can be cut down to judicially manageable standards.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'll give that you on the zone of interests, but there you're dealing with administrative law and a very narrow proposition.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I think it's Justice Kennedy's point, or at least the point of his questions, that these issues meld into the merits and, at least for anyone who is troubled by the idea that we are not going to decide a case even though we have jurisdiction to decide it, maybe that's the better place to address it.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: I'll move to that and take your invitation, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: But before doing so, I would say that if you're going to give me administrative law and zone of interest I think you should then give me Federal common law, which this Court is at its height in terms of fashioning who can come into court and what those rules may be.

American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.speaker: Justice Roberts
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.case_name: American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Connecticut
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, maybe you can tell me in what -- to what extent displacement is different from preemption.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Tell me in this area you're going to have displacement but not preemption.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Or I guess it's the other way around, in which there's going to be preemption but not -- well, what's the difference?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You said in response to Justice Kagan that if they've made a considered decision that this is the amount and no other amount higher or lower, then there would be displacement.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In what way is that different from preemption?

context.speaker: Barbara D. Underwood
context.text: Well, the difference isn't on that front.

American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.speaker: Justice Scalia
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.case_name: American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Connecticut
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --to try to get into the details of how an electricity company will in fact run its operation, than to say all you have to do is make a change in the dollar sign that you charge for your product?

context.speaker: Barbara D. Underwood
context.text: --Well, because we're not suggesting that the court would get into the details on our theory, either.

context.speaker: Barbara D. Underwood
context.text: It would be the defendants that would get into the details, that would figure out for themselves what the best way was to meet these standards -- to meet the objective.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I wish Justice Breyer had made this argument in the EPA case.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't think the EPA case--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.case_name: American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Connecticut
American Electric Power Co., Inc. v. Con.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 20, 2011

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The plaintiff's also raised claims under state tort law.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The courts below did not address the potential governance of state law because we are a court of review.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In that first view, we remand the state law claims so that the lower courts can take them up in the first instance.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Alito has filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment in which Justice Thomas joins.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Sotomayor took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: And I think the Court -- the plurality made quite clear that it would go no further than the facts of Flast.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: And to grant standing here, you have to go -- tremendously depart from what Flast is about: A direct government outlay of funds out of -- taking money out of someone's pocket to fund religion.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I just want to make sure I heard your answer to the -- you said your answer is yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In other words, you agree with Justice Kagan's criticism of those cases and you said, yes, she's right; those cases were wrongly decided.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: They could have gone out -- the results may have been the same.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: It just would have been -- would have been on standing instead of on the merits.

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Kagan
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Paula S. Bickett
context.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Paula S. Bickett
context.text: The Court held that the Department of Revenue could preclude the university from having tax-exempt status because that violated public policy, and therefore they were not entitled to 501(c)(3) status.

context.speaker: Paula S. Bickett
context.text: And so too here, all of these organizations are 501(c)(3) organizations, so they would not be able to discriminate based on race.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Could I try Justice Kennedy's question in a slightly different way.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I'm assuming that you would agree that if this was just a straight tuition voucher program, the State could not give tuition vouchers on the basis of religion, could not say, if you are a Catholic you don't get these tuition vouchers.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But what the State has done here, apparently, is to set up a scheme that uses intermediaries that can make exactly that distinction, that can say, sorry, if you are a Catholic you don't get scholarships out of our STO.

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: We allege they exist and no one doubts that.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I just want to make sure I understand your complaint.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You just said to Justice Breyer that your complaint was that the STOs are giving scholarships based on the student's religion.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I thought another part of your complaint was that the STOs were giving just to the religious schools.

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Scalia
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So the essence of your complaint is that some of the STOs are requiring that the recipient, the recipient child, be of a particular religion?

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: That, and some of the STOs are also requiring that in order to get the scholarship the parent agree to send the child to a particular religious school.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Oh, but that doesn't -- that doesn't get you there.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That doesn't get you there, as Justice Breyer's interrogation indicated.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But you are saying -- you are saying both, is that right, Mr. Bender?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You're saying both of those things?

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Roberts
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: It's not charity.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: Charity is something--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Just to follow up on Justice Scalia's question, because I want to make sure we have the answer: If this system were set up exactly as it is now, but Arizona said contributions to STOs are deductible, you would have no problem?

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: --Contributions to STOs are deductible from one's income tax?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Right.

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Roberts
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: The STO's are a conduit of government funds to the parents.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: The parents are the beneficiaries and the Constitution requires that the benefits of a government spending program go to the beneficiaries on a religiously neutral basis.

context.speaker: Paul Bender
context.text: So in Zelman the beneficiaries were the parents, and the vouchers had to go to them.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry, I don't understand the answer to Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: His question was, you give it to the hospital equivalent of the STO and then that gives it to hospitals on a religiously discriminatory basis.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Why aren't the hospitals the beneficiaries of that program just as you say the parents are here?

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Kagan
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: I disagree -- first is I don't think that is what Flast is.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: I think Flast is about that micro-fraction of a cent that is coming from your pocket and being used to fund religion.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: And that is what Madison complained about, it may be very small, it may be 3 cents, but there is a special harm of conscious when it's your money, your hard earned money being used to fund a program directly as to which you don't like.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Flast talk about a nexus the way Justice Breyer said and here is a taxpayer challenging a provision of the tax code, an active pursuant to the tax and spending power that grants a tax benefit.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That's as close a nexus as you are going to get using the language of Flast.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: Again, I think that doesn't deal with the direct injury on the taxpayer, which is the language of Flast.

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 04, 2011

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: As a result, any injury the objectors may suffer would not be fairly traceable to the State.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And the court order, prohibiting operation of the STO tax credit, would not affect respondents or their tax payments.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because there is no jurisdiction to hear the taxpayers' lawsuit, the judgment of the Court of Appeals must be reversed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Thomas joins.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Kagan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Ginsburg, Breyer, and Sotomayor joined.

Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizona Christian School Tuition Organiz.case_name: Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: As a result, any injury the objectors may suffer would not be fairly traceable to the State.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And the court order, prohibiting operation of the STO tax credit, would not affect respondents or their tax payments.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because there is no jurisdiction to hear the taxpayers' lawsuit, the judgment of the Court of Appeals must be reversed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because there is no jurisdiction to hear the taxpayers' lawsuit, the judgment of the Court of Appeals must be reversed.

Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.speaker: Justice Kagan
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.case_name: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club PAC v. Bennett
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2011

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: In this case, the law provides direct government subsidies, based on my act of speaking, to my political opponents.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: There is, though, a significant difference between Davis and this case.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: What the expenditure triggered in Davis was a discriminatory restriction that would never be allowed in and of itself.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: What the law triggers here is something that, as Justice Ginsburg said, the government could do from the get-go, which is subsidize the speech of a candidate who decides to participate in a public financing system.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: Well, Your Honor, the -- I would point out that independent expenditure groups do not have that choice of participating in the subsidy or not.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: So to the extent that Davis relied on the fact that there was a discriminatory treatment of speakers in the same race, this case -- this law replicates and actually exacerbates the harm that was at issue in Davis.

Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.case_name: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club PAC v. Bennett
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2011

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: If an independent expenditure group speaks in favor of a privately financed candidate, they will not trigger matching funds.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: If they speak against a publicly financed candidate, they will trigger matching funds.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: That not is only content-based; it is also a rejection of the standard this Court enunciated in Citizens United that the government cannot make distinguishing burdens on the basis of an identity of a speaker.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical -- I'm still trying to think about -- suppose there is one candidate for the -- for the pink party, and then three candidates for the orange party, and all three candidates for the orange party received the lump sum Justice Ginsburg was talking about.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But there's only one candidate on the other side, and he has to face, or she has to face, three.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is that constitutional?

Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.case_name: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club PAC v. Bennett
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2011

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So $10,000 by the non-participating candidate triggers off $30,000 against him?

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: That's exactly right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical, wouldn't you have the same problem in different terms, in that one candidate faces three people, all of whom are funded by the -- by the government?

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: Well, this case is not challenging a public financing system, and--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm just asking as a theoretical matter whether there would be a constitutional problem in the case that I put under Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical.

Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.case_name: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club PAC v. Bennett
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2011

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical, wouldn't you have the same problem in different terms, in that one candidate faces three people, all of whom are funded by the -- by the government?

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: Well, this case is not challenging a public financing system, and--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm just asking as a theoretical matter whether there would be a constitutional problem in the case that I put under Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: --Not under Davis, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: How about not under Buckley?

Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.speaker: Justice Breyer
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.case_name: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club PAC v. Bennett
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2011

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And so if it turns out that the States -- public funding isn't being used because -- because the limits are low, and yet the, the State wants to conserve the public fisc.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So instead of just increasing the amount at the outset, it says the -- the -- the object is the same, but we're economizing by not giving it out in one lump sum, we're giving it out in installments.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: Your Honor, in Riley v. National Federation of the Blind, this Court recognized that -- that the government cannot sacrifice speech for efficiency, and what -- if -- if we accept the holding of Davis v. FEC and accept that that is still a holding that is viable under the First Amendment, then what the -- the position of the Respondents is, is that they, in fact, can sacrifice free speech in order to be more efficient, but--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Can you -- can you tell me on that, because I take it you agree with Justice Ginsburg about Buckley.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In Buckley the Court says, public financing is a means of eliminating the improper influence of large private corporations, furthers a significant government interest.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We both agree that's what it says?

Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.speaker: Justice Kagan
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.case_name: Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom Club PAC v. Bennett
Arizona Free Enterprise Club's Freedom C.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2011

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: There is no constitutional objection or at least we're not raising any constitutional objection to the idea that there is a -- that public financing means that people can't run effective races.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: You can have a public financing system with sufficient funds to run an effective race.

context.speaker: William R. Maurer
context.text: But what you cannot do is exactly what Arizona has done, which is turn my act of speaking into the vehicle by which my political opponents benefit.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But that's interesting, Mr. Maurer, because I don't see all that much of a difference between Justice Alito's hypothetical and the facts here.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: In other words, you said that Justice Alito's hypothetical would be constitutional, even though under Justice Alito's hypothetical the State is trying to figure out how much money it takes to run a competitive race and giving people who enter the public financing system that amount of money.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That's exactly what the State is doing here, but it's doing it in actually a more accurate way.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: Bradley S. Phillips
context.text: --Well, Your Honor, I think what it proves is that you -- the key point in here is that initial choice that is voluntarily made by each of the candidates, whether the system of public financing under which you may receive matching funds is better for them or whether the system--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: And that has to do with the independent expenditures.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Let's say there are two candidates running for governor, and one who is a participating candidate is taking a position on a very controversial Arizona issue with which I disagree, and the other is a non-participating candidate who is taking a position on that controversial issue and I agree with that.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The State does this when the opposing candidate has chosen not to accept public financing in the exercise of his First Amendment rights and has engaged in political speech above a level set by the State again in the exercise of his First Amendment rights.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: This goes too far, Arizona's law substantially burdens political speech and does not sufficiently justified by a compelling interest.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is reversed.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.text: Section 3142 says that a detention can only be allowed by a judge if, quote,

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: "no condition or combination of conditions will reasonably assure the appearance of the individual. "

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: And then there's a formal procedure where they have a right to counsel, they have the right to cross-examine witnesses, to -- to present evidence, to proffer evidence at the hearing, and the like -- all to show that they shouldn't continue to be detained.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Well, in light of these restrictions, I would like to come back to the question that I understood Justice Scalia to be asking.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: If the Court were to hold that obtaining a material witness warrant does not violate the Fourth Amendment where the statutory requirements, and in particular establishing materiality, are met, why would it be necessary for the Court to decide whether there's absolute immunity when a prosecutor seeks a material witness warrant?

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: For two reasons.

context.text: Ashcroft deserves neither label because Ashcroft did not violate clearly established law, we need not address the more difficult question of whether he enjoys absolute immunity.

context.text: I think it would be a difficult argument to say that the Secretary was completely without authority.

context.text: This Court's decisions in contract have always held that the objective intent as expressed by the words of the contract are what courts are to construe.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I -- I don't understand why what Justice Scalia said isn't the same as what you said.

context.text: You said no, Justice Scalia, a restatement of contract.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But what he said, the question is whether or not did the parties intend, and it is an objective intent, to confer these rights on a third person.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Interest of States under the Rebate Program sometimes conflict with the interest of 340B entities.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: To ensure operation of the two programs harmoniously, and on a uniform nationwide basis, HHS must hold the control rein.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: For these reasons, developed more expansively in the Court's opinion, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals, our decision is unanimous.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But they're not requiring--

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: --is independently--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --But they're not requiring arbitration--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Go ahead, Justice Sotomayor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --They are not saying you have to arbitration -- class actions in all arbitration proceedings.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: They are identifying a class of cases in which they pursue the State, who's their own sovereign, and the savings clause in the FAA permits them in law or equity to set forth rules to say in this subset of cases there is a substantive right being affected.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --But Mr. Pincus--

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: And so the very same argument being made here could have been made then.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --But, Mr. Pincus, I'm not understanding what test you are asking us to formulate.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Scalia started this by saying, how about a provision prohibiting certain kinds of attorney's fees?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: How about a provision prohibiting certain kinds of -- a law prohibiting certain kinds of discovery provisions?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And you said that would be fine, for the State courts to hold those things unconscionable, but it's not fine for the State court to hold a class arbitration prohibition unconscionable.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why, why, why?

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: But here, that's not -- I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's I think what Justice Kagan is getting at.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If a State wants to have a doctrine which says, you have to have a seal of a certain kind on certain kinds of contracts, they've never done it before, but now they do it, and on that kind you have to have a seal both on the arbitration contract and on the other.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And here what they've done is they have listed the four characteristics from Discover Bank, and they've said all contracts to do with litigation have to satisfy those four.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's I think what Justice Kagan is getting at.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If a State wants to have a doctrine which says, you have to have a seal of a certain kind on certain kinds of contracts, they've never done it before, but now they do it, and on that kind you have to have a seal both on the arbitration contract and on the other.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And here what they've done is they have listed the four characteristics from Discover Bank, and they've said all contracts to do with litigation have to satisfy those four.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: At which point I think Justice Kagan said, so what if they've never done this before?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They sure have done it now.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And what's the basis for saying that the Arbitration Act or any other part of Federal law forbids California from doing that?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Defendants would rarely be willing to bet the company in a class arbitration proceeding with no effective means of review.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Given these considerations, the California law in question stands as an obstacle to the accomplishment of the purposes and objectives of the FAA, it is accordingly preempted.

Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.speaker: Justice Scalia

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: We deal with this at pages 21 and 22 of our yellow brief, and we specifically talk about the fact -- there's several critical facts here.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: One is that the article which was written about the work at Cetus, the JID article at page 135 of the joint appendix, specifically has a footnote indicating that the work reported on -- that is the work at Cetus on the assay -- was funded by the two specific grants in issue.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: Dr. Merigan, who is the head of the lab at Stanford that Dr. Holodniy worked in, talks in his declaration at 98 and 99 of the joint appendix -- specifically talks about how Dr. Holodniy's work was part of the AIDS research center at Stanford and part of an AIDS clinical trial at Stanford, and all of that work was federally funded.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Just -- just as a hypothetical, suppose -- suppose it was as Justice Ginsburg suggested; or indeed suppose this individual even before he was employed by Stanford at all, much less employed by a Stanford project funded by the Federal Government, entered into this kind of an agreement with somebody that he had been working for.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: How -- how would it--

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: Well, I think you have to look very carefully at the facts, and I don't want to speak loosely and categorically about the facts, but what -- what I will say is that in a situation where -- and this is very clearly true -- in a situation where prior work is done by persons who are, to start with a clearer set of facts, not affiliated with the university, and they -- let's say that person conceives of an invention, and that later the university takes that conception of an invention and reduces it to practice.

Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.case_name: Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University v. Roche Molecular Systems, Inc.
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 2011

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --Leaving aside the question of whether that is right or wrong is a matter of contract law, our view is it was not within Stanford's power to essentially convey to the inventor or allow the inventor to retain title, and that's clear in a couple of different respects.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: The provision that Mr. Ayer was reading, section 202(d), says that if the contractor does not elect to retain title, then the inventor can make a request for retention of title, which the agency will consider after consultation with the contractor.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: So the statute doesn't say to the contractor--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but Justice Ginsburg's question, and I have the same concern, is that why can't we resolve this case in a simple way?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What you're asking for, based on submissions to us of amici, of amicus briefs, means a very great change in how -- how -- how patents are held.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: If we can resolve this case on a simple contract basis, why not do it?

Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.speaker: Justice Breyer
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.case_name: Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University v. Roche Molecular Systems, Inc.
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 2011

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They say the strongest analogy is with government employees, and if you look at government employees the basic rule is, the Federal Government paid for it, they should have the invention.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the way they do it is not to deny the employee the right to have the invention, but they insist upon an assignment, assignment of an exclusive license.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And there are cases which are cited here that suggest that, even if the employee tries to run his way around that and simply goes and before the government can get it assigns the interest to a third party, that that third party assignment is void as a matter of public policy; and that the assignment to the government of the exclusive right is valid as a matter of law, a legal implication from the executive order in the circumstance.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That brings me back to where Justice Ginsburg was, and Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The analogy is so strong.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The government has paid for it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: Employees sign either an agreement to assign, as happened with Dr. Holodniy and Stanford here, or, as happened with Cetus, there's a present assignment of future expected interest.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, but the problem with--

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: --I think--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And they're happy because they're -- the value of the patent is not diluted by the fact that the government is going to be doing something with it.

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: --I think in that situation, Mr. Chief Justice, there would be other doctrines that the government or a bona fide third-party purchaser could invoke, including section 261 of the Patent Act or a lawsuit for a reassignment, as is happening in Fenn v. Yale or a--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So at the end of the day, though, your theory is that Congress passed a law that could -- I guess this is Justice Breyer's point -- be easily circumvented not only by the inventor but by the inventor and the contractor working together.

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: --It's not that it can be circumvented.

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: It's -- there are efforts, there are ways in which if there is an inequitable assignment, it can be attacked in equity.

Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.case_name: Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University v. Roche Molecular Systems, Inc.
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 2011

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And there -- there is proof that they can go into court, an employer can go into court and show that the inventor was hired for this specific item and the law would presume or recognize the employer's rights; but why would Congress leave all of that up to the nature of the contract that the university entered into with its inventors?

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: That's precisely what happens in the context of Federal employees, it's governed by the employment relationship between the Federal Government and the employee, and it was shown in the IPA system, in the system that Attorney General Biddle talked about in '47, that the assignment came under ordinary patent law.

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: There was no need for a new--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But the -- but the question I started with and Justice Kagan has picked up on, why would Congress create this act relying on assignments and not have a provision requiring one?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Nothing in the Act, nothing in its regulations, nowhere is there a requirement that Federal contractors seek assignments.

context.speaker: Mark C. Fleming
context.text: --Because there was no need for such a requirement.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: There is something sort of odd about the government's theory that says that I can buy a chemical weapon at [AmazonDOTcom.]

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: That strikes me as odd, and that seems to me the kind of thing where you could make a statutory construction to say, well, maybe sarin or maybe actual chemical weapons, that's one thing, but with respect to this kind of commonly available chemical, to say without any jurisdictional element or anything like that, that it's a Federal crime seems like an argument we at least ought to have standing to make.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What do you say about the one thing -- the strongest point against you, I think, is a single sentence in that TVA case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's only one sentence, but it's there in the opinion, and I think what it's saying, Justice Roberts says, well, he already finished, he just finished saying nobody -- Congress hasn't violated some rule against creating a system of regulation in this statute because it isn't regulation.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But then he said, but even if it were, even if it were, and if your complaint was that Congress has acted outside its authority, which they might have thought at that time, in creating a system, TVA, that competes with local systems, even if that were so, the appellants, absent the State or their officers, would have no standing in this suit to raise the question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay, now, that -- they put quite a lot on to that.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Your underlying premise is that the individual has no interest in whether or not the State has surrendered its powers to the Federal Government, and I just don't think the Constitution was framed on that theory.

context.speaker: Stephen R. McAllister
context.text: Well, Justice Kennedy, I don't know that I would say they have no interest, but I am -- I guess the premise I'm asserting is they do not necessarily get to assert the Tenth Amendment claim of the States.

context.speaker: Stephen R. McAllister
context.text: New York v. United States, for example, was a case where the State initially said we're not concerned about this regulation, and then changed its mind; and the Court in New York said States don't waive those Tenth Amendment rights; States can then -- can change its mind and bring a suit, and there's no indication--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But it does -- it does assume, as Justice Kennedy said, that the reason that is there in the Constitution is only for the benefits of the States, and not for the benefit of the people in the States.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So if a State chooses to give it away, the -- the individual has -- has no standing.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You say it's third party, we're raising the States' rights.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But when those requirements are met as they are here, there is no further restriction applicable to Tenth Amendment challenges.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and remanded.On remand, the Court of Appeals may consider the merits of Bond's Tenth Amendment arguments in the first instance.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But when those requirements are met as they are here, there is no further restriction applicable to Tenth Amendment challenges.

context.speaker: Daniel R. Ortiz
context.text: If, however, it were a one-off allegation that a particular, say, low-level governmental supervisor had engaged in a form of discriminatory activity--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Doesn't that get to the -- to the merits of the case?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You have to from -- you can't invite a question as to whether the sovereign is responsible until you litigate the issue.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what is the -- addressing Justice Scalia's question to you, what would qualify as a petition to the employer as opposed to a petition to the sovereign and why?

context.speaker: Daniel R. Ortiz
context.text: --Your Honor, a petition to the employer about changing the hours of employment--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Those are clear cases.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It seems to me -- the reason I ask is because this seems to me a purely private matter which would not get protection under your test.

context.speaker: Daniel R. Ortiz
context.text: --It's not employment-related or related to his particular job, and this Court has always drawn the distinction there.

context.speaker: Daniel R. Ortiz
context.text: For example, in National Treasury Employees Union this Court applied that kind of analysis.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I see, so that goes back to Justice Scalia's difference test, which is it's not a matter of public concern versus private concern, but it's a matter of employment-related versus not employment-related, correct?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Is that correct?

context.speaker: Daniel R. Ortiz
context.text: Well, that shows how closely those two things have been related in this Court's approach.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Palmore
context.text: But as this Court said in Connick that the question about -- of whether speech is a matter of public concern is assessed not only by the content, but by the form and the context.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Palmore
context.text: So in the case that Your Honor is positing, the content of the -- of the speech, which was that an act of the legislature was illegal, would suggest that it was a matter of public concern, the form, the form of a lawsuit is relevant to the consideration, and the context that it came in part of a larger political debate would likely be relevant, too.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Palmore
context.text: The problem with the Third Circuit approach is that it never engages in that kind of inquiry.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And suppose -- now going back to Justice Sotomayor's example, suppose that there were a -- a class action alleging systemic discrimination in some governmental workplace.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Would that be a matter of public concern?

context.speaker: Joseph R. Palmore
context.text: It very well might be.

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: --I don't -- I don't think -- the specific question is whether the Garcetti rule should apply in a Petition Clause case.

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: I don't think we have a position on that.

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: It's not raised in this case.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Well, Mr. Schnapper, can I ask Justice Kennedy's question in maybe a little bit of a different way?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: In -- in the Connick inquiry, you have a threshold inquiry and then you have a balancing test.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Now, you're suggesting that the threshold inquiry, the public concern inquiry, is kind of apples and oranges here; it's just not appropriate for the Petition Clause.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The framework used to govern Speech Clause claims by public employees when applied to the Petition Clause will protect both the interest of the Government and the First Amendment right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because the Court of Appeals did not find it necessary to apply this framework, there has been no determination as to how it would apply in the context of this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This Court need not consider that question in the first instance rather the judgment of the Court of Appeals is vacated, and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: So it's not just deviant violence.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: It's not just patently offensive violence.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: It's violence that meets all three of the terms set forth in--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I think that misses Justice Ginsburg's question, which is: Why just video games?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Why not movies, for example, as well?

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: --Sure, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Then, presumably, California could regulate movies just as it could regulate video games?

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: --Well, Your Honor, there is scientific literature out there regarding the impact of violent media on children.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: In fact, for decades, the President, Congress, the FTC, parenting groups, have been uniquely concerned with the level of violent media available to minors that they have ready access to.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I don't think; is that answering Justice Kagan's question?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: One of the studies, the Anderson study, says that the effect of violence is the same for a Bugs Bunny episode as it is for a violent video.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So can the legislature now, because it has that study, say we can outlaw Bugs Bunny?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is that -- would you be willing to accept that if necessary to make this okay on its face?

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: Justice Breyer, absolutely.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Morazzini, could I take you back to Justice Scalia's original question, which was what counts as deviant violence or morbid violence.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Because I read your briefs all the way through and the only thing that I found you said that was clearly covered by this statute was Postal 2.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But presumably the statute applies to more than one video game.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why -- why is this particular exception okay, but the other ones that I just suggested are not okay?

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: Well, Justice Scalia, I would like to highlight the fact that the material at issue in Ginsberg was not obscene.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: Under no existing definition of obscenity was the partial nudity that this Court allowed States to regulate minors' access to--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Well, I think what Justice Scalia wants to know is what James Madison thought about video games.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Did he enjoy them?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So what are we supposed to do?

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: Well, Justice Breyer, I think, in going back to Justice Scalia's question, I find it hard to believe and I know of no historical evidence that suggests that our Founding Fathers in enacting the First Amendment intended to guarantee video game retailers a First Amendment right--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Can I go back to what Justice Breyer was asking?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Because this Court, with respect to the fighting words, Chaplinsky's "in your face", provoked an immediate action, the Court has been very careful to cordon that off so it doesn't have this spillover potential.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So you -- you didn't latch on to fighting words.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: Justice Kagan, we welcome that as -- as an effect of California's regulation, but the primary interest was the internal intrinsic harm to minors.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: That's what the State of California is deeply concerned with in this case.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --Can I have a point of clarification?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Ginsburg talked about the labeling parts of this act.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The circuit court struck those portions of the act.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You have not challenged that ruling.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: --My position is that strict scrutiny applies, and that given the facts in the record, given the fact that the -- the problem is already well controlled, the parents are empowered, and there are great and less alternatives out there--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --So when you say--

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: --There isn't any basis to say scrutiny is satisfied.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So just to be clear, your answer to Justice Alito is at this point there is nothing the State can do?

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: Because there is no problem it needs to solve that would justify--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Could I just have a simple answer?

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: Well, if what you are saying is you are going to have a limit on the ability of minors to buy them because of walled off, and minors are not allowed to go pick them off the shelf--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: --then I don't know how that differs from the current law, Your Honor, assuming you could figure out--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Your answer -- your answer to the first question of Justice Alito and the Chief Justice was yes, isn't that -- that you are saying that there is nothing they can do?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So now, am I right about that or am I not right?

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Just temporarily.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: I would think so.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: The intent of the law is to limit minors' access to those games.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Isn't that feedback to Justice Scalia's question?

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: Your Honor, this is a facial challenge.

context.speaker: Zackery P. Morazzini
context.text: This statute has not been applied and not even been construed by a state or federal court below, but.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And if not, whether the regulation of such works is justified by that high degree of necessity, we have described as a compelling state interest, it is not.

context.text: That's generally so in the --

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, did you--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Could you answer Justice Ginsburg's question first?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Justice Ginsburg, I understand what the ordinary rule would be of a court of equity dealing with a constitutional violation, but we are talking about an order entered under the Prisoners Litigation Reform Act, and it's quite clear, the statute couldn't be any plainer, that it shifts the burden significantly onto the plaintiff when you are going to go for a remedy as extreme as insisting that somewhere between potentially 36,000 and 45,000 inmates be released within a two-year period of time.

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: And after all these years, when they -- when they heard the evidence that said that population could be -- and they made the findings which the State doesn't argue were clearly erroneous, and they made those findings that it could be reduced safely, they had an obligation to provide a remedy that would provide constitutionally adequate care in the safest manner possible -- in the quickest manner possible.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I think Justice Sotomayor has been patient.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I have several questions but I'm not sure why -- you have not been responding to Justice -- to the Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Didn't the district court discuss different safe ways of reducing the population?

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Is it a fair statement that the district, that the three judge panel was saying, if you do these things that's their finding, you can do it without affecting public safety, wasn't that what they were saying?

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, if I didn't make that clear, I meant to.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The second more important question was going back to something that Justice Scalia asked you, which was, you made the statement that no one was stopped from proffering evidence about prison conditions up till two months before the trial.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what evidence was excluded?

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Nothing.

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Nothing was excluded.

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Even if the Court made a ruling which was error, which we don't believe it was, there was absolutely no prejudice.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What is the number?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I was puzzled about the same thing that Justice Sotomayor was.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I read on page 253 of the appendix a conclusion where the district court said it is our conclusion that they can reduce this by how many people, what is it, 30,000 -- it's a lot?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The good time credits for older people were -- would have effect, be increased, and also, halfway houses and other kinds of prison facilities which used to be called less -- less physically restrictive punishments, or taking the money you save and building new prisons. Okay, that seems to be the gamut.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is there any evidence, statistically or otherwise because it used to be that States did rely on halfway houses, it relied upon, they relied upon -- they relied upon certain camps -- prison camps, for example -- and some of them were pretty tough and there were a whole range of what used to be called intermediate punishments.

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right is there any statistical evidence on the part -- on the point that Justice Alito raised --

context.speaker: Donald Specter
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: -- as to whether these did or did not result in higher crime rates?

context.text: The relief ordered by the three-judge court is required by the Constitution and was authorized by Congress in the Prison Litigation Reform Act.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I will summarize my dissent which as you've heard is joined by Justice Thomas.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Today, the Court affirms what is perhaps the most radical injunction issued by a court in our nation's history, an order requiring California to release the staggering number of 46,000 convicted felons.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Court disregards stringently drawn provisions of the governing statute and traditional constitutional limitations upon the power of a federal judge in order to uphold -- uphold the absurd.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: And in the 1987 report, Congress made very clear it intended to preserve that case-by-case approach.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: That is set forth at page 50 of our brief, Justice Alito.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: So when one looks at both the words that Congress used in 22(b)(1), the debates that occurred, and the committee reports that explained what Congress is intending here, we believe the intent is unmistakably clear to adopt comment k as a defense to--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But you haven't really answered Justice Alito's question as to why the later language is not surplus.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If indeed it bears the technical meaning you say that it -- that it bears, that later language is surplus.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --It is not surplus if one reads comment k and understands what the drafters there were intending to get at, which was: If, based on current scientific knowledge, the risks are unavoidably unsafe, meaning there is no way in science we can design a safer product, there will be a defense to a claim of strict liability unless or provided that the product is properly manufactured and warned against.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: And he urged there to be a regulatory compliance defense.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So you are asking us to interpret this statute in light of his testimony at a hearing?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: What I'm saying is that Congress had choices, and one of the choices was to adopt a regulatory compliance defense for design defect claims, and it chose not to do that.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It seems to me the language supports the reading Justice Ginsburg has just suggested, or the government has just suggested, with the use of the word "the".

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It says the effects of the vaccine were unavoidable, even though the vaccine was properly prepared.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Your position is, well -- the question is whether it was unavoidable if you could have prepared a different vaccine.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I said the manufacturers' motivations.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: --And -- and, Justice Sotomayor, the reason why the FDA has never had to use that nuclear option is that it -- it works closely with manufacturers long before it needs to be used, and that's because of the rest of the structure of the Act.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: I would like to focus on what Congress did in 1986 in addition to--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Before you get to that, I think your answer to Justice Sotomayor's question is: Nothing; the manufacturers have no reason to take the vaccine off the market until the FDA tells them to.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: --That's not correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: So the -- section 27.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: For a preemption provision to do any work, it needs to attach at the beginning of the claim.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: 22(e), for example, refers to bringing an action.

context.speaker: Kathleen M. Sullivan
context.text: 22(b)(1), to do any work to protect manufacturers, has to attach to prevent the cause of action from being brought.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm still not clear -- I'm still not clear what answer you gave to Justice Ginsburg's question, saying: Why didn't Congress put this out in plain words: There should be no liability for design?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is the answer sloppy drafting?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Are you reluctant to give that answer?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In exchange, they avoid cause of litigation and the occasional disproportionate jury verdict.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Congress enacted this deal to coax manufacturers back into the vaccine market but design defect allegations are the most speculative and difficult type of products liability claim to litigate, taxing vaccine manufacturer's product to fund the compensation program while living their liability for design defects virtually unaltered would be an odd way to make vaccine manufacturer more attractive.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: Now, you might get into--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And that's what -- that's the New Mexico Supreme Court suggested, didn't they?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: They said bring the printout from the gas -- whatever -- chromatograph, and then have an expert who was not the one who certified -- it was not Caylor -- but that here's the graph that came out of the machine, and this is the way this process operates.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I -- in your answer to Justice Sotomayor, did you mean to agree with the New Mexico Supreme Court when they said printout plus an analyst who didn't do this particular run but knows how the process works?

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: --No, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: I'm certainly not here today to agree with the New Mexico Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: When those business records happen to be kept before with the knowledge that they'll probably be introduced at the trial, are there States that require the man or woman who made the business record to come into court?

context.speaker: Gary K. King
context.text: --No, Your Honor, and I think that's the point of all of those.

context.speaker: Gary K. King
context.text: State law has their -- their hearsay law that -- that analyzed whether those statements are admissible.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, I -- I don't think that's an accurate response, at least if you include the qualification that Justice Breyer put in the question, which is that the records were kept with the knowledge that they would be introduced in -- in criminal trials.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, you can say that all the records of labs -- let's assume there's a -- there's a police lab which -- which only does police testing of blood.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Those would be business records of the lab, but they certainly would not be introducible just because they're business records.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But it would make no sense to construe the Confrontation Clause to render inadmissible only sworn affidavits while leaving admission of formal, but unsworn ex parte statements perfectly okay.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And finally, adhere to Crawford and reiterate today, the Sixth Amendment does not tolerate dispensing with confrontation simply because the Court believes that questioning one witness about another's testimonial statements provides a fair enough opportunity for cross-examination.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We, therefore, reverse the New Mexico Supreme Court's judgment and remand for a determination whether the Confrontation Clause error at Bullcoming's trial was harmless, a question on which we express in our view.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed an opinion concurring in part.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
