context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Isn't that -- isn't that the -- the county's claim?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: How Camreta does his job doesn't -- that claim doesn't belong to him; it belongs to the entity who is telling him how to do his job.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And so why don't we go back to Justice Ginsburg's question of why isn't the Monell situation the proper case?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Because there, it's the party interested in how its officers will do their job at its directive.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It has the case and controversy at issue, not S.G.--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --who wants us to Munsingwear.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor, I misspoke.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: It will come up -- if it is as -- if the practice is as widespread as the Petitioners claim, it will come up again in other circuits, and this Court will have the opportunity to review it and--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but Justice Alito's question was addressed to the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In the Ninth Circuit, it's not going to come up again if we assume that our public employees are going to be law-abiding.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They're bound by this in the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: Well, the way that we read the Court of Appeals decision and the rule that we would ask this Court to adopt, that is, seizure and for a custodial interrogation is presumptively unreasonable without parental consent or a court order leaves open the possibility that there are, in fact, some children who are of suitable age and discretion to knowingly make a decision whether or not to talk to an armed police officer and a caseworker without their parents having to make it for them.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: But--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, are you -- I just want to make sure I understand your position.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Answering Justice Scalia's question: Child walks into the room -- is taken out of their classroom, walks into the room.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The officer says: We've heard that your mommy and daddy are doing some things to your private parts; is that true?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And the child says -- 9-year-old child says: I wish somebody had asked me before.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It seems to me that what you--

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: --A seizure, yes, but that would have exigent circumstances, and that would get it out of the warrant requirement.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --Well, but what does that have to do or change the police bringing a child into a room and just asking the question?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: When does -- that's what you seem to have said to Justice Scalia, which is that the mere removal from the classroom is the -- the defining feature of seizure.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So it can't be that.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: --Well, and this -- this Court recognized also that possibility in Ferguson v. The City of Charleston, that the -- the nurses at the hospital would call child protective services, but the -- the -- you have to look at it from the beginning, and in this case, the case began when -- on February 10th, when the police got involved.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: The police did not report the matter to the child protective investigator until 10 days later, and then they went out together.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: Subsequently, the child protective investigator testified before a grand jury as part of the ongoing law enforcement investigation and, in fact, when he was questioned at his deposition, petitioner Alford said that his reason for being at the school was for law enforcement purposes.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: But what is your answer to Justice Ginsburg's question, suppose it was just Mr. Camreta or suppose it was the school nurse, would the answer be the same?

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: No, it would not be the same if it was the school nurse or Mr. Camreta.

context.speaker: Carolyn A. Kubitschek
context.text: And the -- the reason is that the school nurse is part of the school administration, and the school has an obligation and the authority under T.L.O. act and in Earls to make rules and carry out procedures that will protect the children of the school and promote learning, and if the child comes--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Our reason for doing so is that the petitioner through no fault of its own has been prevented from obtaining the appellant review that he's entitled to.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And so, we want to prevent the lower court's unreviewable decision from having any legal consequence.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Here, as I just explained, the happenstance of SG's moving across country and becoming an adult has deprived Camreta of his appeal rights, because mootness has frustrated his ability to challenge the Court of Appeals, Fourth Amendment ruling, we vacate the part of the Ninth Circuit's opinion that addressed that issue.

Chamber of Commerce of the United States.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.case_name: Chamber of Commerce of the United States v. Whiting
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 2010

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: Your Honor, we think that looking at the savings clause -- we don't view it as an anomaly.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: The structure that Congress established is one that the State's authority is determined by the nature of the sanction that we choose to impose.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: We don't have the authority to -- they -- they took away our authority to impose civil monetary and criminal sanctions, but preserved our authority to impose sanctions under this law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But underlying Justice Ginsburg's question is why would Congress want to do that?

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: Well, I think it makes sense, Your Honor, because in terms of licensing, it -- it provides some accountability, because we are the entities that establish policy for our licensees and we are the ones accountable for whether that business remains in business or whether we are taking it away from them.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Perhaps Congress never expected that the States would have to resort to such massive measures, and they probably wouldn't have if -- if the law had been uniformly enforced and vigorously enforced; right?

Chamber of Commerce of the United States.speaker: Justice Breyer
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.case_name: Chamber of Commerce of the United States v. Whiting
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 2010

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: end quote, from the State.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's what the law says, isn't it?

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: That's what -- and that was added after this lawsuit was filed.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I would think that the answer to Justice Scalia's question is, yes, there is that penalty.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It isn't simply hortatory.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: Well, there's no penalty in terms of--

Chamber of Commerce of the United States.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.case_name: Chamber of Commerce of the United States v. Whiting
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 2010

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You are under the old law, and the only sanction is you lose the safe harbor, if that's a sanction.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: That's right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --So in answer to Justice Breyer's earlier question, in fact, relying on the I-9 does not provide a safe harbor, because under the E-Verify system you can't just rely on the I-9 forms and statutes.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You have to rely on the E-Verify.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: Well, Your Honor, we have the same -- it's modelled after the Federal law.

Chamber of Commerce of the United States.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.case_name: Chamber of Commerce of the United States v. Whiting
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 2010

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: Your Honor, my hope is that we--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We are really wasting our time here, aren't we?

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: --My hope is, Your Honor, that we get sufficient guidance.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Wouldn't it be easier, if that is Justice Scalia's concern, to take the Solicitor General's position, that if you are adjudicating good faith or intent differently in any way from the Federal government, that it's granted?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Isn't that what waiting for an as-applied challenge means, whether or not you are putting different requirements on proving good faith?

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: No, Your Honor, and -- because I was trying to give some examples of the kinds of things that may come up as a practical matter, but I think we can get the guidance from this Court.

Chamber of Commerce of the United States.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.case_name: Chamber of Commerce of the United States v. Whiting
Chamber of Commerce of the United States.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 2010

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I see that.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: Certainly.

context.speaker: Mary R O'grady
context.text: So in terms of the prior adjudication--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Just so you know, I interpret your answer as confirming the implication of Justice Breyer's questions that there is a very substantial difference in Federal and State law on this point.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I mean, you told about -- you know what lawsuits are about.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: If you are home free, a driver's license and Social Security inspection under Federal law and you're not under State law, that is a difference.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I don't think that there is any inconsistency between Auer and Mead.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Mead involved the question of whether or not there was -- the court could be confident that Congress had delegated some sort of law-making function to these letters that were written by customs officers across the country to individual importers, when the letters themselves made clear that they couldn't be relied on by anybody other than that particular importer and only unless and until the customs officer changed her mind.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But Mead did put a lot of emphasis on procedural formality.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So, you know, Justice Scalia sort of snidely, but I think accurately, described Mead as saying:

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: "Only when agencies act through adjudication, notice and comment rulemaking, or some other procedure indicating comparable congressional intent, whatever that means, is Chevron deference applicable. "

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So--

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: And when the rate is applied retroactively back to the beginning of the cycle, so this would go back to the first of the month even before the default occurred, as happened in this case, then the problem is exacerbated even more.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Beck, just to clarify your position, if the initial agreement said your rate is 10 percent, but if you are delinquent, your rate will be 20 percent, so not up to 20 percent, just 20 percent, it's an automatic increase in your rate -- in that case, would notice -- would subsequent notice be required?

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: I think if the disclosure was specific and -- and prominent, as required by the initial disclosures, and it wasn't retroactive, then I think the best reading of the rules would be you would not need to disclose that.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So if you don't need to disclose this, and I think that this is the import of Justice Ginsburg's question--

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: --what's the difference between going, okay, we will do the initial agreement, 10 percent to 20 percent; then we can always lower the rate without providing notice; we will go back down to 12 percent, and now you have a 12 percent rate.

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: And we disagree with that as well, first of all because, as I was saying to Justice Ginsburg, you need to have the notice that there has been a change at all in order to -- to realize that you might want to avoid making extra purchases or consider -- not throw away the low APR offer that comes in the mail, for example.

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: And also, aside from that, we think that when you have only a -- a maximum rate, that is basically the equivalent of a range of possible rates between the initial rate and the maximum rate.

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: And that undercuts the ability to compare loans at the time of the cardholder agreement, even before the whole default comes into play, because at that point you have to compare two loans with two possible ranges of rates, and the key factor between the two, the value of the two loans, is how the credit card company will issue -- will use its discretion--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, that's just saying that the problem that Justice Ginsburg is concerned with isn't likely to come up, because a credit card issuer realizes he's not going to get chosen by a consumer if he says your rate is going to be somewhere between 5 and 20 percent.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: No one's going to sign up for that card.

context.speaker: Gregory A. Beck
context.text: --Well, that's -- that's part of the problem, Justice -- Mr. Chief Justice, because the point -- the central motivating purpose of TILA is to provide clear and up-front and specific disclosures, and that -- that would put the burden on the consumer to -- to look into the fine print to figure out the conditions, and after judging all the applicability of those conditions, to figure out how it would apply and compare with other loans.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Likely harm to whom?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think that's the question--

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: --That is the question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --that Justice Kennedy is asking, and I have the same question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Does it mean likely -- is it likely that the class as a whole has been harmed, or that each -- is it likely that each individual member of the class has been harmed?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Or -- or a significant number?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Nobody would understand it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You would have to worry about the time when it was less favorable than the written document.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So call it a plan if you want, as long as you don't mean it's an enforceable contract.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, there is a provision that deals with it, saying just what you said in response to Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And what I don't understand is why wouldn't that provision govern?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I take it there's a provision, 1054(g)(1), that says a plan cannot reduce the rate of accrual of future benefits unless there is written notice in a manner calculated to be understood by the average plan participant.

context.speaker: Stephen R. Bruce
context.text: Now--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So there's some reason it doesn't seem to appear in the opinions.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It doesn't appear in the briefs.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It doesn't appear anywhere until you just mentioned it in response to Justice Alito, or seemed to.

context.speaker: Stephen R. Bruce
context.text: --No, it is in the opinion.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It is?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: It must be an equitable remedy.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: You can seek an injunction.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: And to the extent the Court is concerned that that's an empty remedy, that that's not a sufficient remedy, that's what Congress decided; and we referred in footnote 3 of our reply brief of a number of cases that -- that circuit courts have handled demonstrating detrimental reliance and providing for remedies.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes, but I still have the same question Justice Scalia had, which is why didn't this (h) thing apply here, because they didn't have, their claim, the notice wasn't good, and if the notice wasn't good then the plan didn't change, and if the plan didn't change they should have gotten the money.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why didn't it apply?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: That provision applies to the SPD and they did not bring that case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For example, detrimental reliance would've been and it would be required for relief based on the equitable remedy of the estoppel as it used to be in the Court of equity.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But, its only a showing of actual harm would've been necessary for relief based on the equitable remedy of surcharge for these reasons and those given at even greater length.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In our opinion filed today, we vacate the judgment of the Second Circuit and we remand for further proceeds.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That that was the petition.

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So it doesn't matter what the facts are.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The facts that Justice Kagan gave you would never constitute an actionable claim against a prosecutor; is that your position in this case?

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: That's -- under the Canton hypothetical, yes, it would have to fall on the pattern side because the general Brady situation is unlike the single-incident--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what you--

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --was wrong or not.

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: What we present is the legal theory on which this case was submitted, what got to the jury in the first place, should never have got to that legal theory at all.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You see, what I'm trying to figure out is whether your position is that under no circumstance, even the hypothetical that Justice Kagan set forth, could you be charged with a single incident Canton violation.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That is your -- your theory?

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: With respect to the Brady situation.

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: If you have that situation, then it's closer to the Canton single incident hypothetical, but not involving the exercise of legal judgment in particular cases.

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: We say no.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Well, how do you exercise legal judgment if you don't even know what you are supposed to turn over?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That was Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: That's exactly -- that's my point.

context.speaker: S. Kyle Duncan
context.text: That's my point.

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: "Connick's disclosure policies were no mystery. "

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: "Turn over what the law required and nothing more. "

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: I mean, that would be--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, Justice Alito's question was what you would tell the assistant D.A.'s.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: What's your answer?

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: --And Mr. Chief Justice, with -- if -- first of all, I wouldn't start with that rule.

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: The concept of monitoring and supervision was introduced by the defense, not by the -- by the plaintiffs.

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: But to get back to Justice Kennedy's case--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Could you please state in simple terms to me what exactly they failed to train these prosecutors to do, that the prosecutors didn't do?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What training -- Justice Alito asked it generally, I'm asking specifically -- what is the exact training that was required in this situation that caused the violation in this case?

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: --Number one, there was absolutely no Brady training at all.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Forget about no Brady training.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What training -- Justice Alito asked it generally, I'm asking specifically -- what is the exact training that was required in this situation that caused the violation in this case?

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: --Number one, there was absolutely no Brady training at all.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Forget about no Brady training.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What -- I think Justice Alito asked this question.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What specifically would the training have said or done that would have avoided this Brady violation?

context.speaker: J. Gordon Cooney Jr.
context.text: First of all, I think a broad statement in training about the importance of safeguarding the rights of the accused--

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Prosecutors, in particular, are ethically required to know and follow Brady.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: In the absence of a pattern of previous Brady violations that would demonstrate that further specific training is necessary, a district attorney is not deliberately indifferent when he relies on prosecutor's professional training and ethical obligations.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: A district attorney's office therefore may not be held liable under Section 1983 for failure to train based on a single Brady violation.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Alito joins.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Thomas just reported on dissent from today's decision.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Nearly half a century ago in Brady against Maryland, this Court held that due process requires the prosecution to turn over evidence favorable to the accused and material to his guilt or punishment.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That obligation was dishonored in this case.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I do not suggest that Con -- that Connick can be held vicariously liable to Thompson's ordeal.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: My point is that Connick bares responsibility for his own deliberate indifference to and all too apparent need for on-the-job Brady training.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In accord with the Court of Appeals, and before it, the District Court, I would uphold the jury's verdict awarding damages to Thompson for the gross, deliberately indifferent and long-continued violation of his fair trial right.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Breyer, Justice Sotomayor and Justice Kagan joined me in this dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I do not suggest that Con -- that Connick can be held vicariously liable to Thompson's ordeal.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: My point is that Connick bares responsibility for his own deliberate indifference to and all too apparent need for on-the-job Brady training.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In accord with the Court of Appeals, and before it, the District Court, I would uphold the jury's verdict awarding damages to Thompson for the gross, deliberately indifferent and long-continued violation of his fair trial right.

Costco Wholesale Corporation v. Omega, S.speaker: Justice Scalia
Costco Wholesale Corporation v. Omega, S.case_name: Costco Wholesale Corporation v. Omega, S.A.
Costco Wholesale Corporation v. Omega, S.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 08, 2010

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: It doesn't say categorically all second sales from British publishers are not subject to the first sale doctrine.

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: What it says is in a situation in which rights have been divided and exclusive territorial rights have been given in two different countries, or to put it in copyright language, in the language you also used in the legislative history, when the copyright owner has divided its rights because an innovation of the '76 act, the Copyright Act, the copyrights became divisible.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Where do you get that in the text?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, that's lovely, and you're saying that what Justice Breyer suggests makes perfect sense except for dictum and legislative history.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Does your position make any sense with regard to text?

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: Yes, absolutely, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: --I -- I wouldn't want to commit myself to answering that question affirmatively, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: The Court has said that -- that FELA was enacted to address particular problems in the administration of the common law prior to 1908.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It also said that there's a relaxed standard of causation.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I think that's what Justice Kennedy is referring to when he said "proximate cause light".

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But we have said in more than one case that there is a relaxed standard of causation in FELA cases.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Was that wrong?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Natural, probable, and foreseeable?

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: And foreseeable.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: That -- that language was taken in the Brady case directly from the Court's decision, 1876 decision in the Kellogg decision, which we also cite in our brief, which states--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --Can you tell me -- there is an article that suggests that juries don't actually understand what "proximate cause" means; and I think, and Justice Ginsburg can correct me, that what does that mean to a jury -- natural, probable, and foreseeable?

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: --Well--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Are the three phrases different?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm asking about causality, and what you have just read is "but for" cause.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: Well, I would disagree with that Justice Scalia, and I think the Rogers Court disagreed with that too, because after Rogers this Court upheld in Inman a case on a directed verdict where it concluded after the Rogers instructions had been used that nonetheless the negligence of the railroad had not played a part.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: That's a case involving a drunk driver who hit a flag man at the site of where the flag man was operating.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Can I -- can I go back a second and perhaps follow up Justice Scalia's question in a slightly different way?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Do you believe a railroad can be held liable for a harm it could not reasonably foresee?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Failing to instruct on proximate cause, CSX worries will invite juries to impose limitless liability on railroads.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We see little cause for that concern, instructions like the one given at -- in McBride's case have been read to juries in countless cases over the last 50 years.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Yet the railroad road was unable to identify even a single trial in which such an instruction generated and outlined this award.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Thomas joins all but Part IIIA of the opinion.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed the dissenting opinion in which Justices Scalia, Kennedy and Alito joined.

CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.case_name: CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Department of Revenue
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 10, 2010

context.speaker: Melissa Arbus Sherry
context.text: While Congress intended to provide a substantive right for rail carriers to come into court and claim discrimination on one of the four -- under one of the four subsections, it also intended to provide a Federal forum.

context.speaker: Melissa Arbus Sherry
context.text: And the reason that it did that was because at the time, rail carriers were having a very hard time bringing claims in the State court.

context.speaker: Melissa Arbus Sherry
context.text: The Tax Injunction Act was out there then, as it is now, and it does provide an -- exception, rather -- for when State court remedies are not plain, speedy, and efficient.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I think Justice Kagan meant to ask, assuming that we say yes, it -- it applies; exemptions don't count -- are included in whether there is discrimination, and the Court finds discrimination between the way the railroad is taxed and the way motor carriers are taxed, what -- what then?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What is the remedy?

context.speaker: Melissa Arbus Sherry
context.text: I think in that type of case the remedy would be for the rail carrier to be exempt from the tax, and that's because what subsection (c) provides--

CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.case_name: CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Department of Revenue
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 10, 2010

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: But the answer is: Our argument is to say that we understand from the structure of the statute as a whole that Congress didn't intend to preempt the State's ability to issue tax exemptions.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: May I pose a hypothetical so that I understand?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And I think it follows up on what Justice Alito was saying.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Let's assume all taxes are equal between water carriers and railroads, except there is an excise tax: 4 percent on the railroads, 2 percent on the water carriers.

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: Right.

CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.speaker: Justice Roberts
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.case_name: CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Department of Revenue
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 10, 2010

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That's what railroads do.

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: --Sure.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But it still doesn't get to the question that in courts in each particular case will be able to decide, even under your test, whether it singles out railroads.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The only question I have is that whether singling out means railroads have to be the only business subject to it, or if it has to be, you know, some theory -- Justice Kennedy was looking for a test.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I don't know if we have got a workable one -- to decide when it's really discriminating against the railroad and when it's that the exceptions are just the way taxes normally work.

context.speaker: Corey L. Maze
context.text: And, again, if we adopt a test, which we believe is the right test, the Eleventh Circuit has already done it in this case.

CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.speaker: Justice Kagan
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.case_name: CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Department of Revenue
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 22, 2011

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But those provisions have nothing to say about non-property taxes and so, we can hold and today we do hold that the sales and use tax, unlike a property tax, might discriminate because of its exemptions.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But one last point, we do not decide today whether Alabama's tax in fact discriminates against CSX and other railroads because it exempts their competitors.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Alabama might, well have a sufficient reason to make that distinction and that is a matter for the trial court on remand.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Ginsburg joins.

CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.speaker: Justice Kagan
CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Depa.case_name: CSX Transportation, Inc. v. Alabama Department of Revenue

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But those provisions have nothing to say about non-property taxes and so, we can hold and today we do hold that the sales and use tax, unlike a property tax, might discriminate because of its exemptions.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But one last point, we do not decide today whether Alabama's tax in fact discriminates against CSX and other railroads because it exempts their competitors.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Alabama might, well have a sufficient reason to make that distinction and that is a matter for the trial court on remand.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Ginsburg joins.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: And even the State's own expert, Dr. Stahlberg, after he had actually seen all the documents that he would have wanted to receive if he was doing a mitigation mental health phase, he said it was profoundly misleading.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: And it was.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And this goes back to Justice Scalia's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The question which we granted, question one is whether the Federal court may reject a State court adjudication that Petitioner's claim is unreasonable based on a factual predicate for the claim that the Petitioner could have presented in a State court but did not, and that describes what you are talking about in response to Justice Ginsberg.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, the Petitioner, unaccountably, has told us a few minutes ago that this is a new claim, which I think changes the whole question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The question which we granted, question one is whether the Federal court may reject a State court adjudication that Petitioner's claim is unreasonable based on a factual predicate for the claim that the Petitioner could have presented in a State court but did not, and that describes what you are talking about in response to Justice Ginsberg.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, the Petitioner, unaccountably, has told us a few minutes ago that this is a new claim, which I think changes the whole question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But it seems to me the claim is whether there is ineffective assistance of counsel by reason of the mitigation evidence.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And in that case, we go back to Justice Scalia's opening question to you: Was that the court relied on different evidence, evidence that was not in the State hearing.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And that's the question, whether or not they can do that, if this evidence could have been presented.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And certainly it could have been presented.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Breyer, the Ninth Circuit said:

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: "Although Pinholster substituted experts during the proceeding who ultimately developed different mental impairment theories, these experts nonetheless relied on the same background facts that Pinholser -- Pinholster presented to the State court. "

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: "Accordingly, if 2254(e)(2) were to limit the scope of the evidence before us, it would exclude only the new mental impairment theories introduced in Federal court, and their exclusion would not affect our result. "

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, there you are, and I should have asked Justice Scalia beforehand.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So you are putting your eggs in the basket that under AEDPA, what happened here was objectively unreasonable?

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: Even though he didn't have discovery or an evidentiary hearing, he did allege them, and he should have been given a hearing where he would have then further developed those facts, just as he did in Federal court, when he received the hearing that he should have received in State court but did not.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: There is nothing wrong with that.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: But we don't need that view--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Could you go back to Justice Kagan's earlier question of how we draw the line?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: At what level of generality is sufficient to say that a factual basis of a claim has been developed?

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: --I think we draw the line by focusing on what is legally relevant, not a DSM opinion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: When you say they did nothing, surely that was rhetorical hyperbole, and you took the 6 hours to say this proves what we said, they did nothing; they did next to nothing.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You're not saying, oh well, it was six hours, so we are sorry we said they did nothing.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: --I think what we did is we confirmed the allegation that we had made in State court which is just another example of why it was important based on these allegations for Pinholster to get a hearing to develop the record--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That gets back to the point that Justice Scalia was making, is that this is new evidence that the Ninth Circuit considered with respect to the original.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In other words, they were not just saying, okay, even if none of this happened, we would still rule against you, because one of the new things they had was the 6-hour evidence, which you've just said makes your case stronger.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I think it does make your case stronger, but it also makes clear that we can't say let's just look -- the Ninth Circuit just looked at what was there originally.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Is -- I just want to be as clear as possible.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia read the sentence on page 35.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I read the heading from what Judge Kozinski says,

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: "Our Review is Limited to the Record Presented in the State Habeas Petition: That's what he said. "

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But that's not what it said.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It said exactly what Justice Scalia said it said, so -- which is talking about the evidence coming in under (e)(2) or something.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now I see a nightmare in front of me where I have to go through hundreds or thousands of pages to try to figure out whether they did or didn't mean our review is limited to the record presented in the State habeas petition.

context.speaker: Sean K. Kennedy
context.text: Well, the--

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Looking only at the state record, we find that the California Supreme Court reasonably applied, clearly established federal law.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The clearly established law here is Strickland versus Washington which provides that counsel is constitutionally ineffective only when a defendant shows both defective performance and prejudice.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The California Supreme Court could have reasonably concluded on the record before it that Pinholster could not satisfy either requirement.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: --I disagree, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: During the Linkletter period, the scope of the exclusionary rule for the Fourth Amendment was an essential concern in a series of retroactivity cases, Linkletter being the first, Desist v. United States being the second.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: There were -- many of the Linkletter era retroactivity cases were concerned with the Fourth Amendment exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Yes, but just to pursue Justice Scalia's point: The good faith rule is itself a rule that's intact, that's a precedent, that was on the books, and the good faith rule qualifies the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So why aren't we just following the good faith rule here?

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: The--

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: If this Court adopts a good faith exception that is quite narrow and would not allow an officer in one circuit to reasonably rely on the clear circuit court decisions of another circuit, that's certainly a possibility.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: However, it's not clear as to why the Court would adopt such a narrow version of the exception.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: The language that the government proposes, at least, seems to be the language of qualified immunity; the notion of reasonable reliance on a decision being believed to be lawful.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Kerr, the line that has been suggested by Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy, that is exactly the line that the Eleventh Circuit took; is it not the case?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, Judge Kravitch said: Yes, the Fourth Amendment was violated, so to that extent we're following retroactivity precedent.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But the remedy is something different.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: If this Court adopts a good faith exception that is quite narrow and would not allow an officer in one circuit to reasonably rely on the clear circuit court decisions of another circuit, that's certainly a possibility.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: However, it's not clear as to why the Court would adopt such a narrow version of the exception.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: The language that the government proposes, at least, seems to be the language of qualified immunity; the notion of reasonable reliance on a decision being believed to be lawful.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Kerr, the line that has been suggested by Justice Scalia and Justice Kennedy, that is exactly the line that the Eleventh Circuit took; is it not the case?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, Judge Kravitch said: Yes, the Fourth Amendment was violated, so to that extent we're following retroactivity precedent.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But the remedy is something different.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: That issue, of course, has not been briefed in this case.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: It would remain for the Eleventh Circuit to apply that in the event the Court reverses.

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: At the same time, I wish to be clear that I'm not arguing that the exclusionary rule is available in every case when the Court overturns its precedent, merely that it is a remedy in some cases, and I think it's actually a necessary cost.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: If I could just follow up on Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Why did this defendant have any incentive to bring his constitutional claim if, as may or may not appear too likely, the inventory search is going to result in the admission of the evidence anyway?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It seems that your theory goes too far in saying that defendants will never have an incentive to bring a constitutional challenge if there's some other ground on which the evidence might be admitted, and that's never been our law.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Wouldn't the solution to that be not the rule that you are advocating, but instead a much more limited rule which said that in that case the exclusionary rule applied, but not in any other case, not in any case on direct appeal?

context.speaker: Orin S. Kerr
context.text: --I think Justice Harlan's answer to that is persuasive, that it's inconsistent with basic norms of constitutional adjudication to treat the first case differently from other cases not on -- other cases on direct review.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I guess, Mr. Kerr, I'm not sure that that's right.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Harlan was talking about constitutional rights at a period where, as the Chief Justice said, the exclusionary rule was viewed as part of the constitutional right.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But if this Court doesn't view the exclusionary rule that way any more, if it views the exclusionary rule as simply a prophylactic rule which gives a particular defendant a windfall in order to gain systemic effects, systemic benefits, why would we do it any more broadly than we would need to do it?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And we would just say: Look, we understand your point that this would very much change the incentives for defense counsel.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: The Court has repeatedly rejected efforts to expand the exclusionary rule to serve other purposes, such as schooling judges who issue warrants on the need to respect the Fourth Amendment, reminding legislatures about their obligations under the Fourth Amendment, and for other purposes such as to preserve judicial integrity.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Dreeben, what about Gant itself?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Gant severely qualified Belton.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Should there have been a suppression remedy for Gant, as Justice Kagan suggested, the very case that changes the law?

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Justice Ginsburg, let me give two responses to that.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: First of all, the rule that the Eleventh Circuit adopted in this case, and that is the only rule before the Court, involves a situation in which there is binding appellant precedent that instructs the officer, tells the officer, what you're about to do complies with the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I don't necessarily believe that.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If there's a circuit split and a police officer knows that other circuits are saying this is unconstitutional, why are we taking away the deterrent effect of having thoughts occur to the officer about thinking through whether there's a better way and a legal way to do things?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: With respect to the Fourth Amendment, we've built -- your adversary is right, we've built in so many exceptions, and including in this case the inventory search, that the officers have many different ways of doing things than merely doing what this particular court thought was legal or this circuit.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So I guess my question is, when there's a circuit split, why are we, as Justice Kennedy is saying, giving protection to the circuit that's plain wrong and to the officer who chose to follow that advice?

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Justice Sotomayor, we don't expect police officers to attempt to define the content of the Fourth Amendment on their own.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: They are recipients of the status of the law from the courts that govern their activities; training programs will be instituted based on that law.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: I think it's useful at the outset to look a little bit empirically at that question, because some members of the Court have expressed concern about that possibility.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: From as best as I can tell, this Court has not overruled one of its Fourth Amendment precedents in a manner that favored defendants' interests since 1969.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Despite whatever incentives may have existed as a result of the exclusionary rule, defendants will typically understand that stare decisis is the normal course that this Court follows, and as a result, they are highly likely to structure their arguments in a manner that will seek to distinguish, limit, or undermine a precedent rather than calling for its outright overruling.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Well, particularly in light of that, what is wrong with the suggestion that Justice Kagan raised in one of her questions about retaining an exception to the good faith exception for the situation, for the defendant whose case comes up here and results in the overruling of one of this Court's precedents?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The Court invented the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The Court invented the good faith exception to the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: In cases like this one where the applicable precedent is a decision of a Court of Appeals, this rule will not prevent the development of Fourth Amendment case law since challenges may be brought in other Circuits.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We do not reach the question whether a particular petitioner who obtains the overruling of one of this Court's Fourth Amendment precedents should have the benefit of the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Ginsburg has joined.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We do not reach the question whether a particular petitioner who obtains the overruling of one of this Court's Fourth Amendment precedents should have the benefit of the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Ginsburg has joined.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We do not reach the question whether a particular petitioner who obtains the overruling of one of this Court's Fourth Amendment precedents should have the benefit of the exclusionary rule.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Would that be enough?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: If the government could show it has the right chemical definition, it's rock-like, it's solid, does it have to show anything else?

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: I think that the element of the sentencing guidelines which we're picking up in our second element, Your Honor, is useful in making clear that this is a substance that was -- went from cocaine hydrochloride back to cocaine base, because I think that's one of the--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I'm asking the same kind of question that Justice Alito is asking, whether the government has to show anything particular to demonstrate that it was prepared from powder cocaine.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: --I think that the government doesn't have to produce -- doesn't have to make a physical showing.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: It can -- it is enough for the government's chemist -- and there's always a chemist that testifies in these cases -- to say in his opinion that's true.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: I think -- I think as a fallback we would certainly be happy with the definition that just had the first and the third ingredients in what I've said, but I think the second is important because one of the things that Congress was focused on was the potency of the crack and crack-like substance.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Pincus, you've lost me.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You've responded to the Chief Justice when he raised the problem that this has to be not just cocaine base, it has to be a mixture containing cocaine base, you responded to him by saying: Well, crack always has some mixture in it; it's never -- it's never pure; and that's why crack would be covered.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But in response to Justice Alito, who asked you what if it's pure, if it's pure cocaine base, without any admixtures, you said that would still be covered.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, both answers can't be right.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: I may have misspoken in my response to the Chief Justice, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And it seems to me that's the same thing here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It includes the first, the cocaine, but it has to be within a compound mixture of preparation.

context.speaker: Nicole A. Saharsky
context.text: Yes, you are 100 percent correct, and I think that the statutory language makes that clear because it says it has to be a mixture of substances described in clause (ii).

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Then, Ms. Saharsky, you do get the problem that Justice Breyer was trying to avoid.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That is, on your definition this paste, which is supposed to be less addictive, less addictive than powder, gets bracketed with crack, which is more addictive.

context.speaker: Nicole A. Saharsky
context.text: I don't think that there is evidence that paste is less addictive than powder.

context.speaker: David Sterling
context.text: When that threshold showing is made, the burden is back on the plaintiff to demonstrate the necessary linkage.

context.speaker: David Sterling
context.text: It's not a finding on the merits.

context.speaker: David Sterling
context.text: A determination at the class certification stage is simply one of whether the Rule 23(b) predominance requirement is met and whether the class can appropriately proceed as a class, as opposed to in the traditional individual fashion, and that finding is not binding on the ultimate finder of fact.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Sterling, maybe this is just to repeat Justice Ginsburg's question, but what else is there?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I mean, what would not be proper to introduce in the way that you're talking about at the certification stage?

context.speaker: David Sterling
context.text: Falsity, scienter, actual proof of loss causation, and damages.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: So not all individuals would be protected by the Privacy Act.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: Now, Congress did that, not because had it used the phrase U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Can I ask you a question.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I'm not sure I understood your response to Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If there is ambiguity, if a term can be given two meanings, and it's not clear -- and I know you're challenging the clarity question here -- I thought that Congress's intent to have full disclosure would necessarily mean that where there's ambiguity as to the meaning of an exception then we should change the narrowest meaning.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: Well, I think we disagree, and I think this is why.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: There might not be too many such records.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It -- another reason might be that they don't really care.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Another reason might be -- I don't know.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But if you haven't found any examples, what we're back to -- or -- and maybe there are actual examples of that -- of what you said to Justice Ginsburg of the other instance, where the -- what was that first one?

context.speaker: Geoffrey M. Klineberg
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'd like to know about the example.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The case as AT&T cites from the other areas are too far field from the particular question that issue here to be of much help.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We hold that personal privacy in FOIA Exemption 7(C) does not include the privacy of corporations.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: All members of the Court join the opinion to that effect except Justice Kagan who did not participate in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And the reasoning has been: Well, my goodness, Congress wanted to take care of that larger class; it would be most destructive of the legislative will if we said you can't cover that larger class.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So as a group of unmarried mothers as against unmarried fathers, do -- do you have any notion of what the numbers would be?

context.speaker: Steven F. Hubachek
context.text: Justice Ginsberg, I don't have any statistics to provide the Court.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Maybe this is -- maybe you would like to answer Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: Steven F. Hubachek
context.text: Yes, Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Steven F. Hubachek
context.text: Anyway, the remedy we are requesting is extension.

context.speaker: Steven F. Hubachek
context.text: So even if the Court were to render that decision and someone were to make a claim, they could still say: I had citizenship of as of birth; i.e., whenever I was born, which is before the Court's decision.

context.speaker: Steven F. Hubachek
context.text: So there really -- that would be no remedy at all.

context.speaker: Steven F. Hubachek
context.text: It's a remedy--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But any of -- of the remedies that you are discussing with Justice Scalia involves this Court in a highly intrusive exercise of the congressional power.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let me just ask you this as an analytic matter, or as matter of logical priorities.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We usually talk about substance first, remedy second.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Kneedler, in answering the question that way, I know you are familiar with the Wiesenfeld, case, and the question was, this was a father who was denied benefits to take care of a -- a child whose mother died at childbirth.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And the Court came out a unanimous judgment but split three ways on why.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And one of the members of the Court said, this is discrimination against the child, even though the classification was -- it's called a mother's benefit -- it's discrimination against the child because it should make no difference at all whether the missing parent is female or male, that that was utterly irrational.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That was the Chief -- that was then Justice Rehnquist's concurring opinion in Wiesenfeld.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So he seemed to think that the discrimination was against the child and that that counted for equal protection purposes.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Well, here the only claim that has been raised is an equal protection violation of the parent's asserted rights.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In case 09-5801, Flores-Villar versus United States, the judgment is affirmed by an equally divided Court.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: We would agree with you that the law does require that the defendant intend to prevent a communication.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: The Eleventh Circuit puts the word "possible" in there and says intent to prevent a possible communication.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: And that's the rub, Justice Alito, that we're asking this Court to address.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Going -- going back to Justice Alito's question: Obviously, the statute's not written to say the intent to preclude a witness from talking to law enforcement officials.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If it were that simple about a Federal crime, then it wouldn't matter whether it was likely, possible.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All that we have -- know is that the witness was -- that the killing was intended to stop them from talking to law enforcement, period.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If it were that simple about a Federal crime, then it wouldn't matter whether it was likely, possible.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: All that we have -- know is that the witness was -- that the killing was intended to stop them from talking to law enforcement, period.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So, clearly, (g) has to have a meaning different than merely stopping from someone talking to a law enforcement officer, because there has to be some connection to that officer being a Federal officer.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So, going back to Justice Alito's question, how do you define the intent?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What is the defendant's intent?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If he doesn't have to know it's a Federal officer, what does he have to intend?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Hasn't that defendant violated this statute?

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: We believe the jury would make that determination as to whether or not it was likely, realistically likely that mom would report him to Federal law enforcement officials.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: That's what we're trying to do, is give the lower courts or the -- or the jury--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I don't -- I think Justice Alito can protect his own question, but I don't think you've answered it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You've put in realistic likelihood.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He's asked you whether or not as a matter of law, assuming that you're a juror and you read the statute and you were instructed on the words of the statute and you have Justice Alito's hypothetical, what result?

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: That's what we're trying to do, is give the lower courts or the -- or the jury--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I don't -- I think Justice Alito can protect his own question, but I don't think you've answered it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You've put in realistic likelihood.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He's asked you whether or not as a matter of law, assuming that you're a juror and you read the statute and you were instructed on the words of the statute and you have Justice Alito's hypothetical, what result?

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: --The result of the question of intent?

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: Or what are you asking the result of--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He's asked you whether or not as a matter of law, assuming that you're a juror and you read the statute and you were instructed on the words of the statute and you have Justice Alito's hypothetical, what result?

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: --The result of the question of intent?

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: Or what are you asking the result of--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The reliability under the statute under Justice Alito's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: --Then we would say, yes, that the defendant could be found to have violated the statute under that particular hypothetical.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The reliability under the statute under Justice Alito's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Stephen M. Crawford
context.text: --Then we would say, yes, that the defendant could be found to have violated the statute under that particular hypothetical.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Then Justice Alito's next question -- again, he can protect his own line of questioning -- but what does that have to do with realistic likelihood?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: There's no realistic likelihood; it was only a half of 1 percent chance that the communication would be made.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So, that takes realistic likelihood off the table, and if it's off the table, you have to give us a different test.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: I was going to say it's a fact in the world about something that by -- by the design of the defendant is never going to happen.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: The communication that's at issue when you -- when you don't have the Federal officer's specific intent, is a communication that's never going to happen, and so the jury has to make a reasonable prediction about what could have happened in the absence of the murder.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What do you see--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose in Justice Alito's hypothetical, two guys on the park bench, and they find out that the man with the gray coat behind them was listening.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They say, we have to get the man with the gray coat.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They turn around and they shoot a man with a gray coat, but it's a different man.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: But the statute criminalizes killing someone to prevent the communication, not a communication, not a particular communication, but the communication by any person of information relating to the commission of a Federal crime.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I suspect that what this mainly addressed is -- is killing of witnesses, which has become very common in some jurisdictions, witnesses in criminal trials, and you know darn well what trial is involved.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It's a trial that's already underway, and if it's a Federal trial and you kill the witness, you're -- you're liable under this statute.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What -- what is covered beyond that is if -- if you know that the information is going to be given to a Federal officer, then they have you also, but I don't know why we should read the statute any more broadly than that and -- and have these weird questions submitted to the jury how likely was it that this -- this dead person would have gone to a Federal officer rather than a State officer and -- and inquire into the question that Justice Alito asked, you know, how is there a friendly relationship between State and local officials so that the State official would -- I don't want to get into that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't think the juries do.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: I mean, many of these things are not -- in many of these cases, this is not an element that's difficult to prove.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The problem here is with the words "intent" and "prevent".

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And it's how they're used in ordinary English.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So let me give you an example, even odder than Justice Alito's.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But I think it illustrates the point -- the question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Imagine you put your son in his room, and they say why do you keep your son in his room doing his homework?

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: --Well, we -- again, it depends what it -- what you mean by realistic possibility or likelihood.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: If you mean more likely than not, then we would say that's too high a burden on the government.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: We want to include odd possibilities but not outlandish possibilities.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --I'm not sure I understand your answer to Justice Kagan's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: We -- we -- there's no proof that this particular officer who was shot was going to pick up the phone to the FBI.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: He may have overheard this.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: He would have called his fellow officers, and somebody, probably his supervisor, or the DA's office was going to make the decision whether to call the FBI.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So, how is that different from the cemetery caretaker, who is going to call it in probably to 9-1-1, and he doesn't particularly have an idea of who's going to get involved or not because it's really not his issue.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Why is there a difference between those two situations?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And isn't the question, going back to what Justice Breyer asked, was, what's the likelihood that this is going to get investigated by the Federal Government?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Why is it reasonably possible?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Anything is reasonably possible -- or almost anything.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We find this standard not too strict, not too lenient but just right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And for reasons which we set out at greater length than our opinion, we adopt that standard.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We vacate the decision below and we remand the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
