context.speaker: E. Joshua Rosenkranz
context.text: --Yes, Your Honor, and that's what Hensley says.

context.speaker: E. Joshua Rosenkranz
context.text: Hensley says general litigation is general litigation, and you don't try to parse it out, but if there are -- in the case of plaintiffs, that redounds to the benefit of plaintiffs, because the entire case, all the general litigation, could have contributed to the ultimate success.

context.speaker: E. Joshua Rosenkranz
context.text: When it comes to the defendants, though, the general litigation costs could easily or almost certainly were incurred in connection with the overall defense, and so it makes perfect sense to say to them, break out the pieces, the documents that were really just about the Federal lawsuit.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And Mr. Rosenkranz, in this case what's your understanding of the approximate percentage of time that was spent on the Federal issues that Justice Ginsburg was talking about?

context.speaker: E. Joshua Rosenkranz
context.text: Minuscule, Your Honor, and let me refer the Court to the supplemental appendix.

context.speaker: E. Joshua Rosenkranz
context.text: If you look, for example, on page 30, that's where Vice's expenditures begin.

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: It's a policy choice by Congress.

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: There are burdens allocated to both sides, and there are consequences or may be consequences within a district court's discretion.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --But I thought what Congress said and what we've said in Hensley, that the only thing that the defendant is entitled to fees for is the burden of the frivolous Federal claim.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Your -- your answer to Justice Kagan is suggesting that even if the plaintiff wins, wins everything they were seeking, you're still entitled to 80 percent of your fees, even though the Federal claim didn't add anything to your work -- to your work, except 20 percent?

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: To be clear, Your Honor, I'm not saying we would be automatically entitled to 80 percent.

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: I'm saying Hensley, under the principles of Hensley, the district court would have discretion to award more than 20 percent.

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: And in fact there's even a specific statement in which the city, in an abundance of caution says, just to be clear, there are no State law claims here; and I think the district court is within its discretion.

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: I would point the Court to the cases in which this Court has examined the standard of review for rule 11 decisions, and the Court has held in Cooter & Gell and in Pierce that we give district courts very, very wide berth on these questions, precisely because they're on the ground, they recognize what the -- what the standards are for pleading who is going to be on notice as to what, and this is a funny case in that regard.

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: It's unusual in that these things were really put to the side and parked until the 11th hour.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: In answer to Justice Scalia's question, basically the only difference you have with the -- with the Fifth Circuit is that you would say fees fairly attributable to Federal claims as opposed to fees exclusively attributable to Federal claims; is that correct?

context.speaker: Mark T. Stancil
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So your presumption would be that if the fees are -- support both State and Federal claims, you're still entitled to fees?

context.speaker: Frank W. Heft, Jr.
context.text: --That's -- that's up to the district judge's discretion, whether or not to -- to reduce that -- that amended guideline sentence.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: How is the judge going to decide that?

context.speaker: Frank W. Heft, Jr.
context.text: Well, the -- I think that's something that district judges decide every day, whether or not -- because the judge presumably has -- has been -- is familiar with the case, with the presentence report, with the terms of the original plea agreement, with the facts of the case; and the -- and the judge can make an assessment based on those factors whether or not the sentence reduction should be granted and, if so, how much of a reduction should be granted.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But Justice Alito's hypothetical points out -- points up the fact that even though the agreement may mention the guidelines, it may do that just for the purpose of enabling the -- the judge more readily to approve the agreement, but there's no reason to believe that the government is interested in the guidelines, as opposed to being interested in putting this person away for a certain amount of time, especially when another count is dropped and the government says, well, I'll -- you know, I'll drop it if -- if this guy goes to prison for 2 years.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But if the government had known he's not going for 2 years, he is only going for a year and a half or a year, the agreement might not have been concluded.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So it really -- I mean, it doesn't further the intent of both parties, at least, to say when the guideline is changed, the agreement changes.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: This Court has -- has made clear even after Booker that under 3553(a), courts still need to go through the relevant guidelines analysis.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: They apply the guidelines.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: It may turn out that the sentence turns out not to be based on the relevant guideline range because the judge--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Well, then I'm back with Justice Scalia, because if it's only of legal consequence, not of binding legal consequence, if it's something that somebody considers rather than something that is determinative, it seems to me the same in the non-plea context and in the plea context.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: --Well, I don't think that's true in the context of a specific sentence agreement under a type C plea because of -- and this is reinforced by the language in the policy statement, 1B1.10, which the Court last term in Dillon held is binding and controls what needs to be done during the sentence reduction proceeding.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: And it specifically refers to the guideline provisions that were applied when the defendant was sentenced.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: And so when you have a plea agreement that tells the district judge, you are bound to apply a guideline provision once you've accepted this agreement, we haven't taken the position that the resulting sentence there is not based on the relevant guideline range, but that is not what is going on here.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You want us to decide this case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I completely agree with what Justice Alito is saying, Justice Scalia, that maybe the world after Booker is different.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And I have not thought that one through.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I am thinking this case is a pre-Booker case.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: And so when you have a plea agreement that tells the district judge, you are bound to apply a guideline provision once you've accepted this agreement, we haven't taken the position that the resulting sentence there is not based on the relevant guideline range, but that is not what is going on here.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You want us to decide this case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I completely agree with what Justice Alito is saying, Justice Scalia, that maybe the world after Booker is different.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And I have not thought that one through.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I am thinking this case is a pre-Booker case.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: It's unlike what happens when somebody goes to trial; in those circumstances the judge clearly has the discretion to apply the sentencing guidelines at the time of sentencing.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: It is different from regular type B plea agreements where the parties have come up with an agreement and the judge notwithstanding the agreement is still free to determine the sentence that he or she wants to determine.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: This is a unique -- this uniquely gives a high level of certainty to the parties about the specific sentence that they negotiated.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --I don't -- I am not in disagreement with the point you're making, but I think that going back to what had bothered Justice Alito and Justice Scalia on now that the guidelines are not mandatory, is any sentence even under C really based on the agreement?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Because even a C agreement has to be approved by the judge.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The legal consequence is not the agreement.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: It's unlike what happens when somebody goes to trial; in those circumstances the judge clearly has the discretion to apply the sentencing guidelines at the time of sentencing.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: It is different from regular type B plea agreements where the parties have come up with an agreement and the judge notwithstanding the agreement is still free to determine the sentence that he or she wants to determine.

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: This is a unique -- this uniquely gives a high level of certainty to the parties about the specific sentence that they negotiated.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --I don't -- I am not in disagreement with the point you're making, but I think that going back to what had bothered Justice Alito and Justice Scalia on now that the guidelines are not mandatory, is any sentence even under C really based on the agreement?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Because even a C agreement has to be approved by the judge.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The legal consequence is not the agreement.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The legal consequence is not the agreement.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That doesn't sentence the defendant.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It is the judge's decision as to what the sentence should be which he denotes in accepting the agreement that binds.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And I think -- I may be making Justice Breyer's argument -- that if under the policy statement and it's clear what the judge did here, if the judge feels bound by the agreement or otherwise to calculate a sentence in the guidelines and impose one in the guidelines, how can you say that the legal effect is not the guideline sentence?

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: Well, because I think that the relevant question for purposes of both 3582(c)(2) and the policy statements that the court said in Dillon controls the -- the process of implementing 3582(c)(2), is what did the judge do at the time of imposing the sentence?

context.speaker: Curtis E. Gannon
context.text: And so although it is true that the judge generally will consider how the type C specific sentence that the parties have agreed upon corresponds to a guidelines analysis at the time of deciding whether to accept the plea agreement, the relevant phrase in 1B1.10(b)1 which is -- which is on page 8A of the government's appendix is that the judge is supposed to go back and look at what -- to only make substitutions for the corresponding guideline provisions that were applied when the defendant was sentenced.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, I've written the plurality opinion joined by Justices Ginsburg, Breyer and Kagan.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, the opinion concludes that the Sixth Circuit's categorical bar finds no support in the statute or the rule governing plea agreements or in the guideline policies issued by the Commission.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In the plurality -- plurality's view in every case, the judge must exercise discretion, framed by the guidelines to impose an appropriate sentence regardless of whether the conviction is obtained by trial or by plea.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment but outlining a different approach.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: She concludes that sentence is following plea agreements that bind the District Court to impose a particular sentence, are based on the agreement rather than the guidelines but whereas here, the agreement itself ties the recommended sentence to the guideline's range that a defendant may seek 3582 relief.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In this case, the petitioner is thus entitled to seek a sentence reduction under the statute, and the contrary judgment of the Court of Appeals has reversed, the Chief Justice has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Scalia, Thomas and Alito joined.

context.text: I think somewhere I read that there is a claim that they told you your weight estimates weren't right.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Well -- I mean, there may be a factual dispute, but I'd be -- and I would be happy to litigate that issue if we can get to that point where we are in fact allowed to litigate any aspects of our particular defense.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: But the bottom line here is, and again to state the proposition as starkly as it is because this is the way it comes to the Court from the Federal Circuit, they're saying that the government can assert a claim for $1.35 billion dollars against us and tell us that we cannot defend against that claim even though the reason why we were unable to comply with the contract is because of the fact that the government didn't provide us information either at the outset or as we went along--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: In their rule, if you -- if you follow their rule, they're asking the court to proceed counterfactually and say that they are entitled to not just the 1.35, but the 1.2 billion on top of that, as if they had proved their superior knowledge claim.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: And without having to get to that particular question of whether in fact it's limited to -- whether general jurisdiction is limited to place of incorporation or principal place of business, first of all, there's much more directly controlling authority.

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: In this case, the most directly relevant cases are Helicopteros and Consolidated Textile v. Gregory, working in tandem.

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: In Helicopteros, which was this Court's last corporate general jurisdiction case, the Court said that there was no general jurisdiction based on $4 million in purchases in the State and some other contacts; and the key is that -- on that point, is that the Court held that mere purchases could not provide the basis for general jurisdiction because the pre-International Shoe Decision in Rosenberg was controlling on that point.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Again, this is preliminary and it just goes back to Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose you could help me out.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I assume that there is general jurisdiction over the parent company.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I -- I -- I was wondering why -- why is your interest in this case so much greater than it would be in -- in the other case, and this -- I've been wondering that at the outset, and this sentence that Justice Kagan points out brings that into full focus.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Horwich
context.text: --Well, Justice Kennedy, let me -- let me put it this way.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Horwich
context.text: It -- it -- the difference in our interest in the two cases is at bottom just a difference in magnitude, but we think it's a fairly significant difference in magnitude in the sense -- in the sense that the jurisdictional consequences of an assertion of general jurisdiction are that -- with that one determination it is the case that that defendant can potentially be brought to judgment in a forum for all -- for claims arising from any of its conduct anywhere in the world.

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: Well, Your Honor, I don't -- I don't think our law has a concept of special jurisdiction like that, as consistent with the Due Process Clause, and I think that even -- I won't purport to speak for the Respondents in the other case, but I think that they would probably agree that if the accident had happened to a New Jersey citizen in France, that that would not create, even under their stream-of-commerce theory jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: Under our due process precedents, you need purposeful availment and for general jurisdiction, of course, you need quite a bit more than that.

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: And so while creative, I don't think that would quite carry the day.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: There is a country that has this -- what Justice Scalia -- France in the civil code says that any French citizen can sue anybody on any claim in France.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But we consider that an exorbitant jurisdictional rule.

context.speaker: Meir Feder
context.text: We -- we do, Your Honor, and obviously we wouldn't recognize that under our Due Process Clause, and I think it points up some of the reasons why, at least at the margins, it is important to be able to negotiate treaties so that we can avoid having that sort of jurisdiction exercised against our citizens, just as within the European Community they have an agreement that it's not exercised within that community.

context.speaker: Harry Joseph Colombo
context.text: --which is discussed in our brief, as well as in the reply brief.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, I don't know that you answered Justice Kennedy's question.

context.speaker: Harry Joseph Colombo
context.text: I'm sorry?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I don't know you answered his question.

context.speaker: Harry Joseph Colombo
context.text: What could he have reasonably expected the prosecution's evidence to be?

context.speaker: Harry Joseph Colombo
context.text: How is he going to meet that evidence?

context.speaker: Harry Joseph Colombo
context.text: What tactical or strategic choices--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Sotomayor's hypothetical would include the situation where he doesn't know that the prosecution is going to introduce any expert testimony.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: He knows that there is blood there.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: He should -- he should get his own expert, whether or not the prosecution uses one.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But those resources are diminished and misspent and confidence in the writ and the law it vindicates or undermined, if there is judicial disregard for the sound and established principles that informs it proper issuance.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And that judicial regard is inherent and in the Appeals' Court judgment in this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with the Court's opinion.Justice Ginsburg has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And that judicial regard is inherent and in the Appeals' Court judgment in this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with the Court's opinion.Justice Ginsburg has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: It was all in the context of court-to-court appeals.

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: Bowles doesn't even mention agency appeal of agency action to a court of first review.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what's the rule?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Scalia said those seem to establish a sensible, clear rule, which is if Congress uses the word "notice of appeal", it intends a jurisdictional restriction.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That appears to be the rule that Justice Scalia articulated.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What would be your rule or test now to determine Congress's purpose?

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: Bowles doesn't even mention agency appeal of agency action to a court of first review.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what's the rule?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Scalia said those seem to establish a sensible, clear rule, which is if Congress uses the word "notice of appeal", it intends a jurisdictional restriction.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That appears to be the rule that Justice Scalia articulated.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What would be your rule or test now to determine Congress's purpose?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What -- what of our cases would you point to that establishes different--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Congress couldn't just award money because there has to be an adjudication.

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: Congress would have the constitutional power to just award money.

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: I had understood Justice Scalia's question to be whether--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Scalia just asked you: Could this be -- if Congress decided that this was a harsh result, could it be made retroactive, but for Congress to say, well, just what is it going to rely on to say whether it gives compensation or not?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, the Government's position was he wasn't entitled to compensation for home care, which is what he was receiving.

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Stone was somewhat mixed, though.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It was a motion for reconsideration of the agency, whether or not that told the time to go to the court; am I correct?

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: That -- that's right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's sort of a hybrid problem in the context of Justice Ginsburg's dichotomy.

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: But -- I mean, you are right that that was the issue in Bowles, but -- excuse me, in Stone, but the reason that that mattered in Stone was because the Court held that the timely filing of a petition for review and compliance with the statute was a prerequisite to the exercise of jurisdiction by the court of appeals.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What was the other case that you said decades of -- what is an example of a case where a person, for an incredible, equitable strong reason, such as the wind blew his paper -- I don't know, some tremendously equitable, strong reason he wants review of an agency action--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit affirmed.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: As we explained in an opinion that is filed today, we hold that Congress did not intend that the 120-day time limit be treated as a jurisdictional provision.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: This is specific jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So the question is, when you target the entire United States and each of the 50 States within that and an accident occurs within one of those States, are you subject to jurisdiction in that State for that accident, for a claim based on that accident?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Not generally, but just for a claim based on that accident.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Didn't even Justice O'Connor -- you referenced the Asahi opinions, but Justice O'Connor said as long as there's purposeful availment, there is specific jurisdiction, and there is purposeful availment when there's an active effort to target a market.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: Well, Your Honor, in Burger King, in Hanson, in World-Wide Volkswagen, the purposeful availment is defined as conducting activities within the forum State.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: The -- this Court, through those opinions, foreseeability, clear notice, reasonably anticipate -- all converge.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: There was no written contract between MMA and J. McIntyre.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: There can be an assignment in return for a release of a common law indemnification right.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I don't understand.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Fergenson, just picking up where Justice Ginsburg left off, Ohio is a perfectly good place for jurisdiction over a claim between the British manufacturer and its distributor in Ohio.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Any kind of contract claim, a claim based on the agreement between the two, Ohio is the appropriate place for jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But Ohio does not seem the appropriate place for jurisdiction -- and again, we're talking about specific jurisdiction, not general -- as to a claim based on an accident that occurred in New Jersey.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: Mr. Nicastro could have contacted MMA and stated: I have a strict product liability action -- or the trustee in bankruptcy.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: The statute of limitations was 2 years in both cases.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: Ohio would have applied New Jersey strict liability law.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Your answer to Justice Ginsburg -- I don't want to make your argument for you, but it seems to me all of a sudden you're talking about how Ohio law will help you out.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I thought the question was, from the standpoint of the defendant at least, whether the defendant purposely availed itself of the forum and you would say the defendant here purposely availed itself of Ohio by choosing an Ohio distributor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But you don't make that argument.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Would you say the same thing if, hypothetically, since we're engaging in a hypothetical, the distributor were in France, machine manufactured in England, distributor is in France, and the distributor then selects the United States and then the same facts, New Jersey?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: United States would be an appropriate jurisdiction under the Due Process Clause, but not New Jersey?

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: I think that, with that one step--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: I think that, with that one step beyond--

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: No, it was not, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Arthur F. Fergenson
context.text: It was not told to do anything more than to sell products, not in as many--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Excuse me, counselor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Going back to the relationship, Justice Scalia asked you whether there was legal control, and you said no.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Isn't -- doesn't the record show that the English company traveled to the trade shows with the American company?

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.

context.text: All right.

context.text: What is--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: In -- in my judgment, it's not enough to just have intent, it's not enough just to send the product out on, adrift on the stream of commerce.

context.text: I want to -- you've thought about it more than I.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So--

context.text: I understand that.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, the United States has been telling the rest of the world: We do recognize and enforce your judgments--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Is all that the court in Madras needs what existed here in order to hold an -- an American manufacturer liable?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's -- that's a little scary.

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: Well, Your Honor, if the corporation, the manufacturer is purposely availing itself of the Madras market and hires a distributor to go to Madras and to sell its products, then indeed I don't see why a court in Madras would not have -- and the product explodes or causes some horrific--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --To it really, to you -- are you saying that Justice Breyer's hypothetical creates jurisdiction, that the mere sale to a distributor anywhere creates jurisdiction, wherever that distributor is marketing the manufacturer's product?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I thought because in the hypothetical he created it was they were availing themselves of the U.S. market, that they were marketing, they went to seven trade shows.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: They did merely -- they did something more than the sale.

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: He was prepared to sell to anyone.

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: Whether it was from New Jersey or Massachusetts or Connecticut, it didn't matter as long as the sale was into the United States and the manufacturer got the economic benefit of it.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And Mr. Ross, isn't the point that he was selling by using large convention sites in the United States, expecting that people from other -- would show up to those large convention sites?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I know that Justice Alito doesn't want to hear this, but New Jersey doesn't have all that many large convention sites like Las Vegas does.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Newark is not such a hot place, but they're expecting people from Newark to go and look at these machines and buy these machines.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That's the marketing system that's used for these massive machines that they're trying to sell nationwide.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose there was a little battery or lever that was manufactured, I don't know, in France, and it was sent over to this English manufacturer, and they were -- this part is incorporated in many different kinds of machines, but the part then -- and then the facts are the same: It goes to the Ohio distributor and New Jersey, but the part is what causes the injury.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What result?

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: I would say no jurisdiction for a component manufacturer under those circumstances, unless the component manufacturer was deliberately manufacturing a product for sale into a State in the United States.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Is it your component test?

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: --I think it's -- I think it's the same test, but it would come out differently for the component manufacturer.

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: That's the way I'd like to--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And Mr. Fergenson, isn't that what Justice O'Connor said in Asahi, that the component manufacturer may have all the knowledge in the world -- for Justice Brennan, that was enough; for Justice O'Connor, it was not enough that knowledge was insufficient, that there had to be purposeful availment, that there had to be an active decision, a choice to seek the market.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And -- and I understand that, on your view, McIntyre made that choice.

context.speaker: Alexander W. Ross Jr.
context.text: --Exactly.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That opinion explains that, at least in products liability cases, the sovereign's exercise of judicial power requires some act by which the defendant purposely avails itself of the privilege of conducting activities within the foreign State, thus invoking the benefits and the protection of its laws.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This Court's decision in an earlier case, a case called Asahi may impart be responsible for the New Jersey's Supreme Court's contrary conclusion that the mere placement of goods in the stream of commerce can substitute for purposeful availment.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Although, this Court invoke the stream of commerce metaphor in Asahi, it should be clear that there is no special rule of personal jurisdiction for products-liability cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed an -- an opinion concurring in the judgment joined by Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He argues that none of this Court's precedence would support the exercise of jurisdiction over the defendant by petitioner who had only a single sale in the State as occurred here.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because the incident at issue in this case does not invocate modern concerns, the concurring opinion would avoid using this case as an opportunity to make broad pronouncements on basic jurisdictional rules.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Although, this Court invoke the stream of commerce metaphor in Asahi, it should be clear that there is no special rule of personal jurisdiction for products-liability cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed an -- an opinion concurring in the judgment joined by Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He argues that none of this Court's precedence would support the exercise of jurisdiction over the defendant by petitioner who had only a single sale in the State as occurred here.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because the incident at issue in this case does not invocate modern concerns, the concurring opinion would avoid using this case as an opportunity to make broad pronouncements on basic jurisdictional rules.

J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.speaker: Justice Kennedy
J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.case_name: J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro
J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 27, 2011 (PART 1)

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because the incident at issue in this case does not invocate modern concerns, the concurring opinion would avoid using this case as an opportunity to make broad pronouncements on basic jurisdictional rules.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The petitioner is, thus, entitled to a dismissal of the suit for lack of jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The contrary judgment of the New Jersey Supreme Court is reversed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Ginsburg has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Sotomayor and Kegan joined.

J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.case_name: J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro
J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 27, 2011 (PART 2)

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And cases in which the defendant is a natural or a legal person, whose economic activities and legal involvements are largely home based, one who harbors no designs to gain substantial revenue from sales and distant markets.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This case fits the first category, a local plaintiff injured by the activity of a manufacturer seeking to exploit a multistate or global market.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: On any fair estimate of the inconveniences, Nicastro should prevail before this Court for the reasons just stated developed further in the dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Sotomayor, Justice Kagan and I would hold McIntyre UK answerable in New Jersey for the harm Nicastro has suffered using McIntyre's UK shearing machine at his workplace in that State.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: While I dissent from the Court's judgment, I take heart that the plurality opinion does not speak for the Court for that opinion, takes a giant step back from the course this Court has pursued since International Shoe and would restore a way of thinking about personal jurisdiction long discredited for its detachment from the realities of today's trading relationships.

J. McIntyre Machinery, Ltd. v. Nicastro.speaker: Justice Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And cases in which the defendant is a natural or a legal person, whose economic activities and legal involvements are largely home based, one who harbors no designs to gain substantial revenue from sales and distant markets.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This case fits the first category, a local plaintiff injured by the activity of a manufacturer seeking to exploit a multistate or global market.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: On any fair estimate of the inconveniences, Nicastro should prevail before this Court for the reasons just stated developed further in the dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: While I dissent from the Court's judgment, I take heart that the plurality opinion does not speak for the Court for that opinion, takes a giant step back from the course this Court has pursued since International Shoe and would restore a way of thinking about personal jurisdiction long discredited for its detachment from the realities of today's trading relationships.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why isn't this all subsumed under the voluntariness rule?

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: --As this Court has frequently recognized, the voluntariness inquiry is more difficult for courts to perform than the Miranda custody one.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: And you have also recognized that the court--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, at least it's the court performing it, not the interrogating officer, as Justice Scalia's questions point out.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: --The police officer plays a role in the voluntariness, also.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: And the police officer must be assessing whether the circumstances may be giving rise to an involuntary confession.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But if you're not going to support it, then I've got no support.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: --Well, we're simply making the point that there's not necessarily going to be a floodgate opening.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: And we haven't seen that--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No, no, but I mean what Justice Scalia was really asking is, do you favor something like this test that I read, which is open as to circumstance?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Anything could fit in that blank, as long as both policemen and the -- and the individual know it and it is relevant as to how he understands the circumstance, whether he's likely free to go or not.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: --Conceptually absolutely.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes, that's right.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Even -- even if you said no, you're pushing us there, because there's no basis for treating a childhood any differently from these other factors.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So basically you're saying Justice Breyer would call it objective circumstances.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You know, whether you're mentally deficient, I would call that the subjective condition of the -- of the person being held in custody.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And I think, I don't think that's what we meant by the phrase "objective circumstances".

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, right.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That's my whole point.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: But that is an additional reason why police officers need to be aware of what the age is of a child that they are interrogating because of independent obligations arising out of State statutes.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So is your answer to Justice Ginsburg that, no, the fact that a parent was not notified is not relevant to the Miranda question?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It may be relevant to the voluntariness question.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: No, I believe it remains relevant to the Miranda question, because--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It is, because it's a stop with no reasonable suspicion.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And the kid comes over, and the officer stands him there and continues to talk to him for half an hour.

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: --If there is a custodial -- if we have restraint on freedom of movement which is rising to the degree of a formal arrest, it's a simple enough matter to ask.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So why don't we go back to the test that Justice Breyer suggested, which would answer many of the hypotheticals here, that the objective fact is what is known to both?

context.speaker: Barbara S. Blackman
context.text: What is known to both.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That way you don't get into what the 13-year-old is thinking inside himself or not, because that then becomes subjective; you don't go back to what others might think are special characteristics or subjective characteristics.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So long as the child's age was known to the officer at the time of police questioning or would have been objectively apparent to a reasonable officer, a child's age properly informs the Miranda custody analysis.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The judgment of the North Carolina Supreme Court is reversed.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The case is remanded for the state courts to evaluate whether petitioner was in custody, when police interrogated him, this time taking into account of his age at the time.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Alito has filed a dissenting opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas joined.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So long as the child's age was known to the officer at the time of police questioning or would have been objectively apparent to a reasonable officer, a child's age properly informs the Miranda custody analysis.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The judgment of the North Carolina Supreme Court is reversed.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The case is remanded for the state courts to evaluate whether petitioner was in custody, when police interrogated him, this time taking into account of his age at the time.

context.text: Justice Alito has filed a dissenting opinion in which the Chief Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas joined.

context.text: So long as the child's age was known to the officer at the time of police questioning or would have been objectively apparent to a reasonable officer, a child's age properly informs the Miranda custody analysis.

Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.case_name: Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Derivative Traders
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 07, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: When it -- no, they did it for a business reason, that having separate entities was economically more useful for the market, correct?

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: And every fund, or virtually every fund in -- in the United States, is set up this way.

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: And again--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So -- but that doesn't answer Justice Breyer's question, now.

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: --My third--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Assuming that they didn't do it for that reason, what does it mean?

Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.case_name: Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Derivative Traders
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 07, 2010

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: In fact, no statute says that, and the SEC has never taken that position.

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: There is no case cited in any of the briefs -- they have 234 pages, 138 cases.

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: Not one holds an investment advisor liable for statements of the fund's prospectuses.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Just -- just to clarify Justice Breyer's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In your -- in the hypothetical you gave where the president gives an innocent board of directors false information and the prospectus goes out, is the company liable because their agent -- is the company liable under 10b-5?

context.speaker: Mark A. Perry
context.text: The company may be sued under 10b-5.

Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.case_name: Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Derivative Traders
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 07, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If Janus was not duped, if its board knew and JCM was doing the activity with either the consent or acquiescence of the board, would you have a claim here?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --We would.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: It would be somewhat different because we would plead multiple violators as the court and central bank and from which--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Then go back to Justice Breyer's question, because I can see when there's one primary violator who uses another entity as a dupe or as a puppet, but I can't, and I don't know how to distinguish what you're proposing, from aiding and abetting.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: There has to be something to differentiate the two, so what is it?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --It's the failure on the part of the person who would not have met all of the elements of the 10b-5 claim.

Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.speaker: Justice Kagan
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.case_name: Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Derivative Traders
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 07, 2010

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: And it was that type of usage that brought all of this together.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: The Fund and the management, they are in function essentially one entity.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: The fact that they have contractually outsourced the management function should not alleviate the securities fraud that is alleged here.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Frederick, a substantial part of the power of your argument comes from this notion that, as Justice Ginsburg said, that JCM was in the driver's seat, that JCM had control, that they were -- Janus was at most an alter ego of JCM and maybe something more, that it was just a creature of JCM.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But the securities legislation seems to deal with that in section 20.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And your case is not brought under section 20, and because of the relationship between mutual funds and their investment advisors, presumably could not be brought under section 20.

Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.speaker: Justice Thomas
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.case_name: Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Derivative Traders
Janus Capital Group, Inc. v. First Deriv.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 13, 2011

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: In an opinion filed with the clerk today, we reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for purposes of Rule 10b-5, the maker of a statement is a person or entity with ultimate authority over the statement including its content and whether and how to communicate it.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Here, even if JCM assisted with the drafting of the prospectuses, they were Janus Investment Fund's prospectuses and that company had ultimate authority over them.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Janus Investment Fund, not JCM or Janus Capital Group made the statements.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed a dissenting opinion, in which Justices Ginsburg, Sotomayor and Kagan joined.

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So you mean that if the Government says you've got to file a complaint with us by either calling us or submitting something in writing, and at a cocktail party a worker goes up to a Government employee in that agency, and says, you know, my company is violating the law.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That that's enough?

context.speaker: James H. Kaster
context.text: I don't -- you know, I don't believe that that's -- in the context of a non-work environment, Your Honor, I would note that, I don't know exactly the answer to the Court's question, to be honest.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The reason I'm asking that question is related to Justice Alito's question, which is, what does filing a complaint mean?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Does it have to be relative to the procedures adopted by the person that you are reporting this to?

context.speaker: James H. Kaster
context.text: Filing means directing it to somebody who can do something about it.

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 2010

context.speaker: James H. Kaster
context.text: --If I submit or lodge, that is the -- and it's directed at a particular -- I have to be asserting a statutory right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I'd like to go back to the question--

context.speaker: James H. Kaster
context.text: I am not asserting--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --I would like to go back to the question Justice Scalia filed just earlier.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What -- what would you say about his point that it seems to me had substantial merit?

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --This is the -- this was the Lochner era where they weren't even sure they could do this.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But why should we read their language with a narrow reading of any complaint?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --Well, I think you have to read their language as the way it was written and as the way they would have understood it at the time, which was to file any complaint, which as it would have been understood in '38 and frankly after that, when you file a complaint that usually entails some notion of formality and when you put it in the context of a specific provision where it is not only filing a complaint, but institute any proceeding, caused any proceeding to be instituted, justify any proceeding.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What grievance -- would the bringing of a grievance, the example that Justice Breyer suggested, an employee goes to his union and says, they are violating the statute.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Let's grieve it.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And according to the proceedings established by the employer, they meet with the employer, and the employee does everything in the grievance and they now fire that employee.

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Roberts
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 2010

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: I -- I mean, my own view is the better way of reading -- that is a much closer case, I will concede that, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: My own view is that when you talking about file a complaint, that is just not the way Congress ordinarily thinks about file a complaint.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: File always has in mind written -- I'm sorry.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Scalia's hypothetical, unless I am misremembering, I think, is very common.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: For example, the EEOC, people often file complaints and then the EEOC considers whether it's going to institute a proceeding or not.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Right.

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Breyer
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 2010

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Here we are talking about a Congress that made a very different judgment about how it wanted to protect retaliation.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: And it was a judgment that was made, it seems to me, very much in the context of 1938.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Justice Sotomayor, you are very right; they were not sure they even had constitutional authority to be adopting this approach; and they are attaching to it criminal sanctions, and they are not providing a private right of action; and in that context it seems to me that this Court should comfortably say that this is a much narrower proposition.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about Justice Ginsburg's question?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: I'm sorry?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What about her question?

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Breyer
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 2010

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Certainly not Chevron deference because this is not a--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, Chevron deference would depend on an intent.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I guess you are getting into an argument here that there's no reason to repeat in public.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, Justice Scalia and I don't necessarily agree on this.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why would you--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, I mean, regardless of whether we do, why -- why don't you think we -- we have to give any deference, Chevron -- Chevron deference.

Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.speaker: Justice Breyer
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.case_name: Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp.
Kasten v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plast.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 22, 2011

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Saint-Gobain makes the additional claim that it should win because the Act protects only complaints made to the Government and not as here simply to a supervisor in a private firm.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Because this argument was not properly preserved however, we do not consider it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For these reasons and those given in our opinion filed today, we vacate the judgment of the Seventh Circuit and we remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed the dissenting opinion in which Justice Thomas joins in part.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Because this argument was not properly preserved however, we do not consider it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For these reasons and those given in our opinion filed today, we vacate the judgment of the Seventh Circuit and we remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Because this argument was not properly preserved however, we do not consider it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For these reasons and those given in our opinion filed today, we vacate the judgment of the Seventh Circuit and we remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed the dissenting opinion in which Justice Thomas joins in part.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
