context.speaker: Joshua D. Farley
context.text: Once he knocks on the door and hears noises consistent with the destruction of physical evidence, then an exigency has arised.

context.speaker: Joshua D. Farley
context.text: Now the officer has both probable cause and an exigent circumstance--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But I don't understand why the smell of marijuana is necessary.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: This goes back to what Justice Sotomayor was saying, you don't need probable cause to knock on a door.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Knocking on a door is perfectly lawful.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So, if there's just a lawfulness test, the knock is fine.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That if that's reasonable foreseeable, says the court, then that violates the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But we have the Second Circuit that says as long as the police behaved unlawfully -- it -- lawfully, lawfully, it does not violate the Fourth Amendment; and we have the First Circuit that has some kind of bad faith test plus an unreasonable or improper test; and we have the Fourth and Eighth circuits that yet have some different kind of test.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And one of the things I would be interested in hearing your view on at some point is just what the Chief Justice said; that assuming from your point of view this is a hypothetical case, nonetheless we would like your view on which of those tests or some other test is the appropriate test and why.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That was the question he started with, and Justice Kennedy started with, and I also would be interested in your view on that.

context.speaker: Jamesa J. Drake
context.text: --The appropriate test is the test that we propose.

context.speaker: Jamesa J. Drake
context.text: Under our test, the police act unreasonably when they convey the impression to an -- to a reasonable person that entry is imminent and inevitable.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If, indeed, there -- there was a threat of imminent entry, we're going to bust down the -- if that was the threat, then it's unlawful, surely.

context.speaker: Jamesa J. Drake
context.text: Yes, and that's why my answer to Justice Kagan's question was to the extent that unlawful and unreasonable are synonyms, we would agree.

context.speaker: Jamesa J. Drake
context.text: Now, if the Court is not terribly -- does not find our test convincing, the next-best test, we believe, is a foreseeability test.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If your test is something novel -- Justice Breyer mentioned there are some five tests in the different circuits, and the foreseeability test is the one that the Kentucky Supreme Court used, but is your -- does your test coincide with the tests of any other circuits or is it different?

context.speaker: Jamesa J. Drake
context.text: Our test is a novel test.

context.speaker: Jamesa J. Drake
context.text: It has not been, to my knowledge, considered by any of the other circuits.

context.speaker: Joshua D. Farley
context.text: Officers should not be held accountable for unlawful reactions by suspects.

context.speaker: Joshua D. Farley
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, counsel.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You will have noticed that Justice Kennedy left the bench a few minutes early.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: He is going to Tucson to represent the Court as the circuit justice for the Ninth Circuit at the memorial service there.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: He will review the tapes and transcripts of the rest of the argument and fully participate in the decision.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito has the opinion of the Court this morning in Case 09-1272, Kentucky versus King.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: He has asked that I announce it for him.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: This case comes to us on the writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: They did not violate the Fourth Amendment, nor did they threaten to violate the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Under these circumstances, the officers' warrantless entry to prevent the destruction of evidence was reasonable.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We therefore reverse the judgment of the Kentucky Supreme Court and remand for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Ginsburg has filed a dissenting Opinion.

Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.speaker: Justice Alito
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.case_name: Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: --Well, but it might not, Your Honor, because it might turn just on whether -- I mean, Ex Parte Young suits against State officials are under 1983.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: And so to some, I think the argument that Petitioner would make is if causation is required under 1983, well, Ex Parte Young is just a vehicle to get those people -- to make those people person.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: So whatever the Court were to decide about causation wouldn't necessarily apply in those Ex Parte Young issues.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: I have a question similar to Justice Sotomayor's.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Suppose we were to hold that the Monell requirement applies to prospective relief, injunctive and declaratory relief.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Can you provide an example of just an unacceptable consequence that would follow from that holding, a situation in which that holding would, in your judgment, be one that we would not want to accept?

Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.speaker: Justice Breyer
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.case_name: Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: I guess the way I would look at the case is, if the party who is being injured filed suit against the municipality and against the official and said, I would like a marriage license, that, as the court heard the case and found yes, there is an unconstitutional denial going on there, the fact that the lawsuit existed and there was an ongoing violation that had been by virtue of the lawsuit brought to the attention of the policymaker, and if in that case the judge decided that prospective relief is necessary, which necessarily means that there was some finding of ongoing violation under Lyons and those cases, that there would be a link to the municipality.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: And my concern is not that properly applied causation requirement would weed out cases.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: It's that because the focus of the Court's jurisprudence up till now has not been on the ongoing violation as the possible source of a policy, but rather was there a policymaker involved in the initial denial, unless if the court were to say there's an extra step, it would make very clear that the focus of attention is not the initial action, in terms of finding a policy, but on the day -- as the matter ends up on the day the district court is deciding whether or not to grant relief, that those facts are relevant in deciding whether there is a policy, as well.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What is the answer to Justice Alito's question?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The -- a clerk doesn't give a license to someone he should.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Right?

Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.speaker: Justice Roberts
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.case_name: Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If you are right about that, there is no problem for you, because you are saying: Yes, you need a city policy, and this counts as a policy.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: That's exactly right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: And our concern is that the Court's jurisprudence, because it has been focused on retrospective one-off, for the most part, actions, doesn't make clear what the answer is in that situation.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer's question said you need a city policy, and you said that's exactly right.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So I think the case is over.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The issue is whether you need a city policy, and your friend thinks so, and you think so.

Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.speaker: Justice Roberts
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.case_name: Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: I think it's the ongoing conduct, almost certainly, maybe it would be a question of fact, will by virtue of the lawsuit be brought to the attention of the policymakers.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Oh, sure.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You are back where Justice -- Justice Alito was commenting, well, that at some point you have to bring what you were complaining about to the attention of the city.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You dismiss that as an exhaustion requirement, but--

context.speaker: Andrew J. Pincus
context.text: No, I'm not -- I don't think that courts have said that filing a lawsuit is an impermissible way to do that.

Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.speaker: Justice Breyer
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.case_name: Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries
Los Angeles County, CA v. Humphries.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 30, 2010

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And for these reasons, which we explain more fully in our opinion, we conclude that Monell's policy or custom requirement applies in Section 1983 cases, whether the relief sought is monetary or whether it is perspective.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And we reverse the Ninth Circuit's contrary determination.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The decision is unanimous.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Or the jury?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the same is true of scienter, after all, because the scienter -- and you have to plead that with particularity.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What's your answer?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What's -- I mean, Justice Kagan had an interesting view of this, and it could be that she's putting forward and others might have a different view.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Who is to decide this?

context.speaker: Jonathan Hacker
context.text: Well, ultimately it's a question -- it would go all the way to the jury if the plaintiffs were able to plead facts in the complaint that entitled them to--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I know.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I know, but over--

context.speaker: Jonathan Hacker
context.text: --but look at the allegations--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --We're not saying -- you're saying if you are a scientist -- now we're back to Justice Scalia's questions and the--

context.speaker: Jonathan Hacker
context.text: --But it matters what a scientist would think because it's only then that anybody ex ante, again, remember--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --Well, then what--

context.speaker: Jonathan Hacker
context.text: Well, in terms of scienter, under the securities law there has to be a plausible basis--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, you got cert granted on a limited question, and the limited question was whether in a complaint that alleges only adverse reports can you prove materiality and scienter without proving statistical importance.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's the question presented.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Kagan started with the point that the FDA doesn't require that.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It requires just reasonable evidence of a connection, not statistical.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Many of the amici here have done a wonderful job of explaining why statistical importance can't be a measure because it depends on the nature of the study at issue.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Many of the amici here have done a wonderful job of explaining why statistical importance can't be a measure because it depends on the nature of the study at issue.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So given all of that -- and even in your brief, in a footnote, you answered the question by saying, no, we can't establish that rule as an absolute, because there are additional factors that could prove materiality and scienter.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So you've already answered the question presented.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Are we down to what Justice Scalia asked you, which is: We got a no to the question: Are the facts in this case enough?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I don't know why we would have granted cert on that, but you presented a different question presented.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Given the question presented, is the answer no?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If it was the only product, they sold that might be enough, five adverse reports out of ten million?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If -- if that's the only product they make, you say, totality of the circumstances, that may be enough?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --Under the Basic test, Your Honor, that very well might if the probability and the magnitude of the harm -- if those five incidents were deaths from a product that was easily substitutable, that might be a relevant decision and information that investors might want to take into account.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In response to Justice Alito, I heard you say something about a scientifically plausible link?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That seems to me to be a rather significant concession.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And that answer is a reasonable one.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We therefore defer to the agency's view that medical residents are workers who study not students who work.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And that means that we affirm the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eight Circuit.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: All members of the Court joined the opinion to that effect, except Justice Kagan who did not participate in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Stephen C. Gordon
context.text: So -- so, the 1 year in the violent felony provision is not serving the same purpose that -- that the 10 years is in the serious drug offense.

context.speaker: Stephen C. Gordon
context.text: A reason that Congress may have had for doing that is to say that if we are going to hit somebody with 15 years, we want to make sure that they had their constitutional rights at the time they sustained the predicate conviction, had a right to counsel, indictment, jury, and so forth.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I'm -- I'm not sure what you're urging now.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Are -- are you modifying or retracting the answer you gave to Justice Sotomayor, that is, the case where the maximum was 5 years, but then at the time of the Federal offense the State has changed it so it's 10 years?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I -- I think you answered her question that it would work the same way, that what mattered is how the State currently ranks the offense, not the offender.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But now you seem to be saying there might be a different answer when the State increases rather than decreases the penalty.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Only when he's excited, right?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Only when the victim who has been the object of a violent crime is excited.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Or if State law doesn't apply and we are dealing with a Federal crime and Federal officers, right, and trial in Federal court?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And in that case, what Justice Breyer just said would not apply.

context.speaker: Lori B. Palmer
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Lori B. Palmer
context.text: And I--

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: Well, certainly.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Under the Federal Constitution?

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: The Federal Constitution--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think your answer, counsel, is that we decided that in Crawford from which Justice Breyer dissented.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Suppose I think he did it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Perhaps there is another answer that I would like to hear.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It is an exception from hearsay, for certain, but from the Confrontation Clause?

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: --I'm not -- if I -- if I meant -- if you took what I said as a concession, what I said is that this--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You conceded it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It's been the whole basis for Justice Ginsburg's subsequent interrogation.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: My question was based on its an open question, because we have said maybe dying declaration.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: --And I--

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: Are we referring to a specific person?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I mean, that strikes me as something that happened in the past, he shot me, but at the same time demonstrates an ongoing emergency because he is right there and he might shoot you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm suggesting the line you propose to Justice Alito doesn't work.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: Well, I -- I -- I would -- I don't -- I don't think that -- that the -- the -- the discussion of verbs tense and past tense, I don't think that is the -- is the -- is the determining factor.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: It's certainly important, certainly a relevant consideration in--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay, okay.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I forgot.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: --What -- the difference that made in Davis is that the -- the definition of testimonial is not across the board.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I guess it depends on what you mean, by in the past, as Justice Breyer put it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Undoubtedly under the regime of United States v. Reynolds which was what, 25 years old -- when--

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: Roberts.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: Roberts.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Roberts.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Reynolds was the Mormon case -- which was about 25 years old or so when Crawford was decided, yes, hearsay was your protection, and that was it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But if by -- what you had mean is in the past, Crawford examined the past and its conclusion as to what the past said is quite different from what Justice Breyer now says, although he joined Crawford.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Peter Jon Van Hoek
context.text: As you said, in Crawford this Court looked at that and though the protections of the hearsay rule, and the focus under the Roberts standard of whether a statement fell within a firmly established hearsay rule, was not sufficient under the Constitution, under the Confrontation Clause, to -- to alleviate the fact that there -- there is no cross-examination.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: The officers all arrived at different times as repetitive questions and generally did not conduct the structured interrogation.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: For the four going reasons, we hold that Covington statements were not testimonial and that their admission at Bryant's trial did not violate the confrontation clause.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: We reversed the judgment of the Michigan Supreme Court and remand for further proceedings not inconsistent with our opinion.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed an opinion concurring in the judgement.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Scalia and Justice Ginsburg have each filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: For the four going reasons, we hold that Covington statements were not testimonial and that their admission at Bryant's trial did not violate the confrontation clause.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: And I guess I would say this is just one aspect of the patent law's balancing of competing interests in a way that doesn't serve either to the exclusion of the other; and to use an obvious analogy, the current term of patent protection is 20 years from the -- the date of the application.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: Obviously Congress thought 20 years was better than 10 and presumably that was because 20 years gives greater incentive to innovation.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: If somebody asked--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Why is -- why is re-examination sufficient to answer the concerns that Justice Breyer mentioned, when re-examination can't consider certain issues, and a case such as this doesn't necessarily have to be stayed while re-examination takes place?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --It's not fully sufficient to resolve all challenges to the -- the validity of an issued patent.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: Now Congress now has it before it legislative proposals, one of which has passed the Senate, one of which has been voted out of committee in -- in the House, and is currently pending before the court -- the full -- full House of Representatives, that would expand the availability of post, what we now call post-grant review proceedings, where for a limited window of time after a patent is issued, people who oppose the issuance of the patent can come in and object on any ground.

context.speaker: David S. Mann
context.text: So there is a clear sharp dividing line.

context.speaker: David S. Mann
context.text: And as this Court said in Rose, actually quoting Vaughn, we needed that sharp dividing line to let agencies know--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, in Rose we talked about a legitimate public purpose in seeking information.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I tie my question to Justice Alito's, which is at what point does -- is it legitimate for the public to seek information, internal information relating to the rules and practices of personnel?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Can the public seek information that places the community at a severe security risk?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Is it possible for us to say that that kind of information, given our line of reasoning in Rose, could not be legitimate public information?

Milner v. Department of the Navy.speaker: Justice Scalia
Milner v. Department of the Navy.case_name: Milner v. Department of the Navy
Milner v. Department of the Navy.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: David S. Mann
context.text: It's how the Navy stores and moves its munition around.

context.speaker: David S. Mann
context.text: So even under a reading of -- of Crooker, what Crooker was looking at, looking at the House report, taking the House report on its face, taking the testimony before Congress that was on its face, again, that was still dealing with these operating rules and guidelines for government investigators or examiners.

context.speaker: David S. Mann
context.text: Not--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Mann, I thought you disagreed with the premise of Justice Ginsburg's question; that is, that you assert that the language related solely to the internal personnel rules and practices of an agency is quite clear.

context.speaker: David S. Mann
context.text: --I do.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought maybe you were abandoning that.

Milner v. Department of the Navy.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Milner v. Department of the Navy.case_name: Milner v. Department of the Navy

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: So there are things -- for instance, if the rule is that you need to file a FOIA request in a certain way, and the agency instructs personnel to process it in a certain way, those rules also would affect the public.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: The public would need to comply.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: If there is a dual purpose, a dual function of the rule or practice, it would not relate solely to the internal personnel rules.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Well, that begs, I think Justice Scalia's question.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: One could argue that everything that the agency develops except rules telling the public how to come to the agency with a complaint, et cetera -- virtually everything will govern either the internal personnel practices or the agency's practices vis-a-vis the public.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: But not everything that the agency does will relate solely or exclusively to govern the internal personnel -- the rules and practices for personnel.

Milner v. Department of the Navy.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Milner v. Department of the Navy.case_name: Milner v. Department of the Navy
Milner v. Department of the Navy.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: One could argue that everything that the agency develops except rules telling the public how to come to the agency with a complaint, et cetera -- virtually everything will govern either the internal personnel practices or the agency's practices vis-a-vis the public.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: But not everything that the agency does will relate solely or exclusively to govern the internal personnel -- the rules and practices for personnel.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: When there is a dual function, that is it both instructs personnel how to do their duties and it's also something that the public must take into account--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, if the -- if the agency has a rule that says put explosive A in building 1 and put explosive B in building 2, that's hard for me to explain that it's just a personnel rule, other than, as Justice Scalia says, everything, all functions have to be undertaken by humans.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: --Well, I -- I don't know that I would agree with that.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: I think the personnel rules and practices that are at issue here are a complex set of rules that are based on types of munitions, the--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: In addition, Exemption 1 prevents access to classified documents.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: That exemption ensures that the Government can withhold documents whose disclosure would compromise national security.

context.text: We hold today just one thing that the government cannot withhold these records on the basis of an exemption that covers and was meant to cover only employee relations matters.

Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.case_name: Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 10, 2011

context.speaker: Steve Bullock
context.text: What page was it?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I thought you referred us, just while you're going through your notes, to page 82, and there's an intriguing footnote where the special master talks about his own -- his own book.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But that doesn't seem to me to be conclusive on your point, because he's saying the area is confused.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And his point it seems he brings up what the special -- I'm taking over your answer to Justice Scalia's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It is page 282.

context.speaker: Steve Bullock
context.text: Footnote 15, yes, Your Honor.

Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.speaker: Justice Breyer
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.case_name: Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 10, 2011

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Are you saying that "depleted" means only what's withdrawn and it's not calculated by -- with reference to what is returned?

context.speaker: Peter Kenneth Michael
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Obviously you're saying -- to read it with a different emphasis.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia read it with -- beneficial use is that use by which the water supply of a drainage basin "is depleted" when usefully employed by the activities of man.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And you read it, by which the water supply of a drainage basin is depleted

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: "when usefully employed by the activities of man. "

Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.speaker: Justice Roberts
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.case_name: Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 10, 2011

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And your best authority for that is?

context.speaker: Peter Kenneth Michael
context.text: The best authority, I think, is the Special Master's discussion of this, that the only practical way water supply of the drainage basin would be -- the quantities of water in the rivers themselves would be depleted would be through a diversion.

context.speaker: Peter Kenneth Michael
context.text: So there's really no reason to make a distinction.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Just to follow up on Justice Kennedy's point, because I think it's important: So you were reading -- when it says "is depleted", you think all you have to show is that it's less than when you started, and once that is shown, it is depleted.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Then you're saying, but we can deplete as much as we want?

context.speaker: Peter Kenneth Michael
context.text: Yes, depletion would be moving it from this glass of water, if that was the river, and it reduces the quantity of water in the river.

Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.speaker: Justice Thomas
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.case_name: Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota
Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 02, 2011

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Under that doctrine, efficient sprinkler, irrigation systems are permissible even if they cause a net increase in water consumption.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: This is true so long as the sprinkler users do not increase the amount of water they divert from the river or use the conserved water to irrigate new acreage.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Accordingly, Montana's allegations that Wyoming has violated the Compact by merely allowing the installation of more efficient sprinkler systems fails to state a claim.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.speaker: Justice Thomas

Montana v. Wyoming and North Dakota.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 02, 2011

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: This is true so long as the sprinkler users do not increase the amount of water they divert from the river or use the conserved water to irrigate new acreage.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Accordingly, Montana's allegations that Wyoming has violated the Compact by merely allowing the installation of more efficient sprinkler systems fails to state a claim.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: If the Government's collection of information or the disclosure of the information burdens some other fundamental constitutional right, that is certainly one limit.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: So if the Government were collecting information, Justice Alito, on sexual practices of its employees, it may burden the exercise of other rights.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Yes, but that's putting those aside.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I mean, what about some of the hypotheticals that Justice Alito posed?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Your diet?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That's certainly relevant in the employment context, right?

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: --Justice Sotomayor, the narrow rule is what we said in our petition and what we said on the very last page of our reply brief and all throughout, which is, this Court should simply say what it said in Whalen, which is assuming that there is some informational right to informational privacy.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: The -- the use of a background check with accompanying safeguards to collect information doesn't violate the constitutional right to privacy.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Well, why wouldn't that violate it if the question involved a fundamental right?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: If you were asking the question that Justice Alito asked, which is, what's your sexual practices in the bedroom, if there are security checks against you disclosing it, you are saying even that would be okay?

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: I could imagine a circumstance far afield from this one in which the Government's just mere collection of information about sexual practices might burden the exercise of those rights.

context.speaker: Neal Kumar Katyal
context.text: I'm saying it's not at all present here, and I don't think the Court should get into it.

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: --That -- yes, it is.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So that's all information about yourself?

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I think what Justice Breyer is getting to and that I'm trying to figure out is, you've used the word "privacy".

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: What does privacy relate to?

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: --Privacy relates, in this case, to the--

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Because as broadly as you have defined that, it would include all of that.

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: It -- the -- the nature of what is included can be intruded upon based upon a governmental need.

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: So if there is a rational basis for knowing Social Security Numbers, driver's license, census information, that type of information, then -- then there is not an issue.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So this gets back to Justice Sotomayor's earlier question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You said if there is a rational basis, so is that the test?

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: The test--

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Kennedy
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So they want to find out information relevant to suitability for employment.

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: --And for security clearances.

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: Those are the two issues.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I -- I have to agree with the implication of Justice Ginsburg's remark, at least what I imply from it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Look at the private employment sphere.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It seems to me that for a sensitive position, a bank who has people taking care of -- its employees taking care of other people's money, or the medical profession, that the employer could be sued and would be remiss if it did not ask this question.

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 05, 2010

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: --Only if you need to know the answers.

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: And for the snack bar worker or the GS clerk-typist, for those types of people who have no access to sensitive information, do not -- it can -- the definition here is that these are noor low-risk -- they are low-risk employees, which is defined as, if they misuse their position, they will have little or no impact on the agency mission.

context.speaker: Dan Stormer
context.text: So we know that these questions are being asked of people who, if they completely misused their position, there will be no impact.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So -- just to -- I would like to get back to Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So now you not only have to decide which questions -- they can challenge any question they want and say, this isn't pertinent, but you also have to categorize which employees are being asked that question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: This is a -- SF means "standard form", right?

National Aeronautics and Space Administr.speaker: Justice Alito
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.case_name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration v. Nelson
National Aeronautics and Space Administr.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 19, 2011

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: These inquiries are reasonable and they further the Government's interest in managing its internal operations and responses to the challenge, inquiries are shielded from public disclosure by the Privacy Act.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Those protections are sufficient to satisfy any privacy interest that may arguably be rooted in the Constitution.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We reversed the Court of Appeals' contrary judgment and remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.

Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.speaker: Justice Breyer
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.case_name: Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 2011

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: And this is the first case that I'm aware of, it's the first time anyone has said it to my knowledge.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: I don't even know of law review articles that said it before basically the decision that is under review for neutral laws of general applicability.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: But to return to Justice Kennedy's question, what this law--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You agree with Justice Scalia?

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: --I agree emphatically with Justice Scalia, except that I could never put it as well as he did.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're ending up skirmishing on what seems to me a less significant aspect of this case.

Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.speaker: Justice Roberts
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.case_name: Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It seems to me that just opens, opens the door to future litigation challenging ethical rules, which -- which does not make me happy.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: It is true.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: And in addition to that, to expand it even more, apply it even more broadly, with the exception of essentially the D.C. Circuit's opinion in Clarke v. United States, this is the first opinion I'm aware of where anyone has even held that there is a First Amendment interest in any sort of expressive official act.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You modified your answer to Justice Scalia by saying you're not aware of any case that applied the First Amendment to rules of general -- neutral rules of general applicability, I think.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But if the First Amendment doesn't apply, that doesn't matter, does it?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You can't limit your -- the type of rules that you say are not -- are okay and are not if the First Amendment doesn't apply at all?

Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.speaker: Justice Breyer
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.case_name: Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 2011

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The statute says "or advocate the passage of".

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So I guess that's speech.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: But, Justice Breyer--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the -- I mean, the basic question is, again, do you agree with Justice Scalia's question, the import of it; or don't you?

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: --But Justice--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If it doesn't apply, if voting is not speech, then no matter how outrageous the law or rule, it doesn't fall within the First Amendment; and if it is speech, then you get into some of the questions that were raised, is this too vague or is it not?

Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.case_name: Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 2011

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: But I mean they -- if you look at the opinion at pages 105 to 106 of the Pet.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: App, it's clear that they're looking at the business relationship.

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: It's relevant, certainly, to have helped him win three elections, because that's relevant to the closeness of their personal relationship, but--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I think Justice Breyer's question -- he can tell me if I'm wrong -- is whether that argument by them was actually raised below the way he is stating today?

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: --I'm sorry?

context.speaker: John P. Elwood
context.text: I -- the argument by the--

Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.speaker: Justice Scalia
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.case_name: Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 13, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Carrigan puts forth -- forward two other reasons why in his view Nevada's recusal statute is unconstitutional including the fact that it is unconstitutionally vague.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But since neither of those reasons was passed upon by the Nevada Supreme Court or mentioned in Carri -- Carrigan's brief in opposition to the petition for certiorari, we decline to reach them.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court of Nevada is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion, and Justice Alito has filed an opinion concurring in part and in the judgment.

Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.speaker: Justice Scalia
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.case_name: Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan
Nevada Commission on Ethics v. Carrigan.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 13, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Carrigan puts forth -- forward two other reasons why in his view Nevada's recusal statute is unconstitutional including the fact that it is unconstitutionally vague.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But since neither of those reasons was passed upon by the Nevada Supreme Court or mentioned in Carri -- Carrigan's brief in opposition to the petition for certiorari, we decline to reach them.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court of Nevada is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion, and Justice Alito has filed an opinion concurring in part and in the judgment.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: The additional point about your--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But that's not the point that you have made here, I mean, and that is not the point on which we granted certiorari.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: --That's right and I think -- I think what I just said about the 50(b) point is that I think it highlights that this really was a summary judgment review by the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Mills, if I could just understand your answer to Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You concede that the Sixth Circuit opinion is using the record built on the whole trial and that that's a different record from the record that existed at summary judgment; is that correct?

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: I do concede it, except to the extent that I concede they did an adequate review of the record.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: The example I gave about this point where Mrs. Bright conceded on cross that Ms. Ortiz indeed would have been separated and the assault, second assault, precluded, it's one of two things.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: Either the Sixth Circuit's reviewing summary judgment and picking a couple of trial facts it thinks helps to review and missing the facts; or it's doing -- it's looking ahead at these trial facts and because -- particularly because the district court never weighed in on that, on a Rule 50(b), it's botching the record.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: And it goes to the heart of this Court's cases from Cone v. West Virginia Pulp & Paper in 1947 up through Unitherm, which says we have to have the district court review the sufficiency of the evidence before the court of appeals could even have the power to possibly consider this.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That answer is not addressing Justice Alito's point, which he said a Rule 50 motion is not jurisdictional.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You are in essence claiming it is.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You are saying they lacked the power, but Justice Alito's question to you said they don't, that they've misread the fact that this is not a jurisdictional motion.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: And it goes to the heart of this Court's cases from Cone v. West Virginia Pulp & Paper in 1947 up through Unitherm, which says we have to have the district court review the sufficiency of the evidence before the court of appeals could even have the power to possibly consider this.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That answer is not addressing Justice Alito's point, which he said a Rule 50 motion is not jurisdictional.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You are in essence claiming it is.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You are saying they lacked the power, but Justice Alito's question to you said they don't, that they've misread the fact that this is not a jurisdictional motion.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So address that question: Why is it jurisdictional as opposed to a claim processing?

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: Your Honor, I am not disputing that the Sixth Circuit had jurisdiction to consider the case.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: There are purely legal components to those inquiries; there is no doubt about it.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: Again, a purely legal question might be what is the constitutional right; is it clearly established.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Well, that's what I'm asking.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I'm asking is -- is -- are the questions that you have those sorts of questions, or are they factual inquiries that would fall on the other side of Justice Breyer's line?

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: At the end of the day these are factual inquiries in which you have to understand the officer's conduct.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: All I'm saying is that the second component to establish immunity or anything else does include always a pure question about whether the right's clearly established.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: Actually, Your Honor, the summary judgment motion was only one of several orders listed in the notice of appeal.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: And the Sixth Circuit brief was couched as an appeal from the verdict, which at the bottom of the prior page of the petition appendix, from where Justice Kennedy just read, the bottom of page 7a, the Sixth Circuit calls it an "appeal from the jury verdict".

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: And then the Sixth Circuit at petition appendix 2a and throughout its opinion refers to "trial evidence".

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But, Mr. Mizer, then you must concede that this opening sentence that Justice Kennedy just quoted is wrong.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Courts normally don't review the denial of summary judgment motion after trial on the merits, but when the summary judgment denial is based on qualified immunity, there's an exception.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: I think that what the Sixth Circuit meant there was that the issue of qualified immunity raised in summary judgment was preserved.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: I think Unitherm was more squarely the latter, although the Court did refer to the Seventh Amendment in responding to Justice Stevens' dissent.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: And the Seventh Amendment concerns I don't think are implicated here, because it is well established that legal claims like qualified immunity are not for the jury to resolve.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: And so taking -- taking the case away from--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, then you are saying, the category -- the mixed claims -- as Justice Breyer proposed, if it's a purely legal claim, then you're right.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If it's a mixed claim, then you're wrong.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: --And I think those -- those categorization are -- are fairly slippery and would be difficult to apply, as I think the Chief Justice suggested.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: --Well, qualified immunity is always going to be an application of clearly established law through fact.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: And Mitchell notes that -- that there will be some--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but we have been through this.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I think it was Justice Alito gave the hypothetical, suppose everybody agreed on what happened, the question is whether or not the right's clearly established.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: --And that is--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's a pure issue of law.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: The -- the -- Ms. Ortiz has also posited that a collateral order appeal is a requirement in order to preserve a qualified immunity claim.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: That argument is clearly foreclosed not only by the broad agreement among the circuits, but also this Court's decisions in United States v.--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: When you go back -- you are the one who read these cases pretty thoroughly, and as I looked at it, I -- with the incomplete knowledge, I would have thought that Justice Ginsburg's statement of it is basically right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What Rule 50 is about is sufficiency of the evidence.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And 50(a) involves, we are saying it won't be sufficient.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What's the big deal?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Make the motion.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: Because, Your Honor, the district courts have never insisted, nor do the rules insist, that the district courts get multiple cracks at a legal question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The purpose of -- of 50(b) -- Justice Alito brought out that it's not simply the historical background of the Seventh Amendment, but in that same line of cases, the court gave a practical reason.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And the practical reason related to the district court, that if the motion is made after the jury comes in, the district judge would have the opportunity to exercise her discretion to grant a new trial.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Let's take -- is it Ms. Bright where the Sixth Circuit said that, well, maybe there could have been a retaliation claim, but the Plaintiff didn't make it?

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: --That's correct, Your Honor, and the lower courts, I think, are well-equipped to assess whether or not an issue has adequately been pressed and passed on in the district court.

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: That has been the settled rule of appellate reviewability, and I don't think that it should be changed by imposing a Rule 50(b) requirement for anything other than a sufficiency of the evidence motion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I just want to be clear.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Your answer to Justice Kennedy had the caveat that except for the issue we addressed in Unitherm?

context.speaker: Benjamin C. Mizer
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: That's the position of the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: You say if you want counsel judgment, simply make your motion.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: But I would add that whichever way this court goes, the decision here has to be reversed, because there is no doubt that the legal issue of qualified immunity at summary judgment depended entirely on the officer's conduct at trial.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So your rule, in response to Justice Sotomayor, would basically require anyone who has an assertion of qualified immunity to take their collateral appeal or interlocutory appeal.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: It would only require it, Your Honor, to the extent that they wish to challenge that decision on the summary judgment record.

context.speaker: David E. Mills
context.text: I am not at all suggesting that that appeal is required to preserve the issue of immunity.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The challenge's sufficiency of that evidence, a defendant can move post verdict for judgment as a matter of law.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Jordan and Bright did not do so, nor did they request a new trial on the ground that the weight of the evidence favored their qualified immunity defense.

context.text: But--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And Congress' essential purpose in enacting this part of the Code was to ensure that debtors who can pay creditors do pay them.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So once again, we think this means that a person like Mr. Ransom who doesn't have any car-ownership expenses shouldn't be able to deducts them when calculating how much he has available to repay creditors.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: We therefore affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which previously disapproved this deduction.
