context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's why it's so unrealistic to handle it that way, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Robert C. Owen
context.text: --Well, Your Honor, I think -- I'm not sure I agree that it's unrealistic.

context.speaker: Robert C. Owen
context.text: I mean, I think that over time the courts who are wrestling with this issue in the wake of Osborne will identify what aspects of a State's statute and construction of such statutes violate due process or don't.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Why isn't a correct formulation of your answer to Justice Scalia to say what we are seeking is a determination that the State court's judgment, the State court's decisions, State court's order was a violation of due process?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: If you say that--

context.speaker: Robert C. Owen
context.text: That's a much simpler answer, Your Honor, I will adopt that answer.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So look at Dotson.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Dotson says that you go into habeas if winning -- i.e., getting the DNA -- would necessarily spell speedier release.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: End of the matter.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm reading to you from Justice Scalia's concurrence where he quotes my majority with great praise.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: Justice Scalia -- Justice Scalia also makes the point at the end of his Dotson concurrence that the question -- the real question is whether you could make out this type of claim or this -- make out this type of proceeding in habeas.

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: As Justice Ginsburg noted earlier in the argument, the Court has dealt with these issues in a -- in a variety of cases, most of them being prison disciplinary or parole-type proceedings.

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: And in those cases the Court is trying to define the outer bounds, ultimately of what we're going to say Prieser/Heck required to be brought in habeas, and what may be brought.

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: A couple of boundaries on those rules at first; Prieser and Heck make--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Coleman, if you could answer Justice Breyer's question, because there are two phrases, necessarily imply the invalidity of the conviction and necessarily spell speedier release; and either you think that your case fits one of those or both of those standards, or you are asking us to abandon that standard.

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: --I don't think that that's true.

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: I think that what the Court has always recognized, an article 64 proceeding is a motion in the criminal case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The library.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I want to use the prison library, same example.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I want to use the prison library 9:00 to 3:00, because that's when I work on my efforts to upset my conviction.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now -- I mean, it's the same as Justice Kagan--

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: --That's a condition--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --provided.

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: And at the end when you recognize what he is trying to do, this is fundamentally a question or a -- he is seeking to invalidate his conviction and that it comfortably fits within the policy choices that the Court has made all--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So -- so the--

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: --the way.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --Justice Ginsburg's question I think is an important one.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Are you going to argue that you fit within -- this case fits within "necessarily implies" or is there another formulation that you think we should have?

context.speaker: Gregory S. Coleman
context.text: We think given the nature of the Article 64 proceeding, which is itself an attack on the conviction, it is a request that the Court declare that the conviction is probably invalid, that because that is what he is attacking, he is saying the result that is--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We express no opinion on the ultimate disposition of Skinner's federal action.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We know however, that the Court's decision in Osborne severely limits the scope of the federal action a state prisoner may bring for DNA testing.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Osborne rejected the extension of substantive due process to this area, and left slim room for the prisoner to show that the governing stat -- state law denies him procedural due process.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Kennedy and Justice Alito joined.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We express no opinion on the ultimate disposition of Skinner's federal action.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We know however, that the Court's decision in Osborne severely limits the scope of the federal action a state prisoner may bring for DNA testing.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Osborne rejected the extension of substantive due process to this area, and left slim room for the prisoner to show that the governing stat -- state law denies him procedural due process.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Kennedy and Justice Alito joined.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We express no opinion on the ultimate disposition of Skinner's federal action.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We know however, that the Court's decision in Osborne severely limits the scope of the federal action a state prisoner may bring for DNA testing.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Osborne rejected the extension of substantive due process to this area, and left slim room for the prisoner to show that the governing stat -- state law denies him procedural due process.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Kennedy and Justice Alito joined.

context.speaker: Richard A. Monahan
context.text: Now, certainly other issues -- if we're talking about policy concerns, another thing I would note is that in CAFA recently -- whenever Congress adopted CAFA, certainly if they believe that basing one -- using one class denial in Federal court as a basis to preclude all other similar classes seeking -- seeking certification, if they thought that was consistent with due process, certainly they could have considered adopting that as part of CAFA.

context.speaker: Richard A. Monahan
context.text: But they chose to deal with it in a very different way, a very different manner, and that was to go ahead and change the jurisdictional status and diversity cases, make minimal diversity and allow removal with certain -- certain exceptions for certain discretionary ones, stay at home and local controversy exceptions, but they didn't -- I mean, that's how they chose to deal with it.

context.speaker: Richard A. Monahan
context.text: Now, certainly we would admit that since CAFA has been enacted, the chance -- certainly there's not nearly as many of these cases which will occur where this will be an issue, because many large classes now will get removed.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: When -- when Congress enacted CAFA, did Congress think about this precise issue, the issue that Justice Ginsburg is raising about a lawyer going from State to State with a different named plaintiff?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Was that -- was that part of what Congress was reacting to?

context.speaker: Richard A. Monahan
context.text: Yes, Justice Kagan, it's my understanding that that was something they were concerned about.

context.speaker: Philip S. Beck
context.text: It's posed in some of the other cases percolating up, the Thorogood case, for example, or some of them out of the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Philip S. Beck
context.text: I think that under normal preclusion analysis, decisions that have not reached the point where there's a formal final judgment can still be given preclusive effect if they're sufficiently final, that a court says it's exceedingly unlikely that we could reconsider.

context.speaker: Philip S. Beck
context.text: There's another--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's true about -- that's true about preclusion, but -- and so that you might go into the West Virginia court and say this second plaintiff should be precluded, but as Justice Kagan pointed out, you're dealing with the anti-injunction statute that talks about judgment.

context.speaker: Philip S. Beck
context.text: --And I was about to say, Your Honor, that -- that under the Anti-Injunction Act it might actually be a different analysis, and because the issue isn't present here, we haven't briefed it, but I could see under the -- looking at the statutory language of the re-litigation exception that talks about judgments and also looking to the Federalism concerns that -- that inform the -- the Anti-Injunction Act, one could argue, in an appropriate case, that whatever the law is as to preclusion generally, when it comes to the Anti-Injunction Act, we're going to require more in the form of a -- of a formal judgment that -- that incorporates the particular ruling.

context.speaker: Philip S. Beck
context.text: As I said, that's not our case, but--

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So for this reason too, the District Court was wrong to enjoin the state court proceedings.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Because the Court of Appeals affirmed the District Court's conjunction, we must reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The opinion of the Court is unanimous.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Thomas joins only Parts I and IIA of the opinion.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So I think what I got from your brief is you don't fall under that case because you are not dealing with a public figure.

context.speaker: Sean E. Summers
context.text: --That's correct, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Were you finished answering Justice Breyer's question?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The more you say about this the happier I will be, because I'm quite interested.

context.speaker: Sean E. Summers
context.text: The private targeted nature of the speech in our judgment is what makes it unprotected.

context.speaker: Sean E. Summers
context.text: The--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But you are saying yes.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So public speech, speech on a public matter, if directed to a private person, should be treated differently under the law?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I think that was part of what Justice Breyer was asking.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Is that what your position is?

context.speaker: Sean E. Summers
context.text: --Public speech, even directed to a private figure, should be treated differently than as directed towards a public official.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Because it's not specifically prohibited by the statute.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, it certainly wouldn't be because of the distance.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, you would have to be a lot closer than the Maryland statute allows to spit in someone's face.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Perhaps you would like to answer Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Sean E. Summers
context.text: --I believe that you could commit a tort and still be in compliance with the criminal code, Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Summers, can I ask you: Suppose I don't think you have a cause of action for invasion of privacy when these people were at this distance from the funeral.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Is that your argument?

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: --With a -- yes, Justice Alito, and with a little bit more from your cases, if I may: And not under an inherently subjective standard, and where you're only claiming that the impact of the speech was adverse emotional impact.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Well, Justice Kagan gave you one example.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Let me give you another example along the same lines.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Let's say there is a grandmother who has raised a son who was killed in Afghanistan or in Iraq by an IED.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: Let us assume that the grandmother had not done what Mr. Snyder did in this case.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: Mr. Snyder from the moment he learned of his son's death went to the public airways multiple times in the days immediately before and immediately after--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Do you think that everybody--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: What is your answer to Justice Alito's question?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Do you think the First Amendment would bar that cause of action or not?

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: --There would have to be a very narrow circumstance where it didn't, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The person selects the grandmother because he thinks that will give maximum publicity to his views.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Now, is -- does the First Amendment bar that cause of action or not?

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: If the grandmother entered the public discussion, the First Amendment bars it.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, no -- Justice -- Justice Alito posed, the grandmother was returning from the grave of her grandson.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: She didn't enter the public discussion at all.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So I'm anxious to determine whether in those circumstances you think the First Amendment allows that cause of action or not.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: That makes him -- that makes her a public figure?

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: It's getting closer.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: And Justice Alito, if she went on then to say, and how many more parents like me and my ex-wife are going to have to suffer this way and when will this senseless war end, and I've gotten Congressman Murtha on the phone and talked about this situation, and I'm against the war, and then proceeded to repeat that question in the public airwaves repeatedly, then a little church where the servants of God are found say, we have an answer to your question that you put in the public airwaves and our answer is you have got to stop sinning if you want this trauma to stop happening--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Your response -- your response to Justice Alito is dwelling on the facts of this particular case.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: --Yes, sir.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm interested in knowing what your position is on the broader question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But that's simply--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Excuse me--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --That simply points out that all of us in a pluralistic society have components to our identity; we are Republicans or Democrats, we are Christians or atheists, we are single or married, we are old or young.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Any one of those things you could turn into a public issue and follow a particular person around, making that person the target of your comments; and in your view because this gives you maximum publicity, the more innocent, the more removed the person is, the greater the impact -- the Justice Alito hypothetical in -- in -- in the grandmother case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So I -- I think -- I think your -- your public concern issue may -- may not be a limiting factor in cases where there is an outrageous conduct and where there should be a tort.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: Well, but again, this Court has given substantial, longstanding protection to speech on public issues, and how could it be gainsaid that the dying soldiers is not on the lips of everyone in this country?

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: And it is a matter of great public interest and why they are dying, and how God is dealing with this nation.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: Were you to consult the Joint Appendix and see that at the very same funeral, right outside the front door of the church, were people with flags and signs articulating the "God bless America" viewpoint, and so this little church--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But your position is you can take this and you can follow any citizen around at any point?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That -- that was the thrust of the questions from Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: --Not follow--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And -- and Justice Alito, and it seems to me that there -- you should help us in finding some line there.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But your position is you can take this and you can follow any citizen around at any point?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That -- that was the thrust of the questions from Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: --Not follow--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And -- and Justice Alito, and it seems to me that there -- you should help us in finding some line there.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: --Yes, I will help you, Justice Kennedy and I am pleased to do that.

context.speaker: Margie J. Phelps
context.text: Because we don't do follow-around in this church.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: As a nation, we have chosen a different course to protect even hurtful speech on public issues to ensure that we do not stifle public debate.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That choice requires that we shield Westboro from tort liability for its picketing in this case.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That choice requires that we shield Westboro from tort liability for its picketing in this case.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What result under the statute?

context.speaker: Bridget C. Asay
context.text: --The statute would have required the pharmacy to prevent the further dissemination of the data except for health care research.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --You answered my question earlier that they don't sell it to anyone else.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's why I was trying to clarify your answer to Justice Kennedy, because you told me the only sale -- the pharmacists, they sell this to the data miners, they do not sell it to the other people.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But now you're answering Justice Kennedy's question, yes, they sell it to universities.

context.speaker: Bridget C. Asay
context.text: I apologize, Your Honor, if I was not clear.

context.speaker: Bridget C. Asay
context.text: --The statute would have required the pharmacy to prevent the further dissemination of the data except for health care research.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --You answered my question earlier that they don't sell it to anyone else.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's why I was trying to clarify your answer to Justice Kennedy, because you told me the only sale -- the pharmacists, they sell this to the data miners, they do not sell it to the other people.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But now you're answering Justice Kennedy's question, yes, they sell it to universities.

context.speaker: Bridget C. Asay
context.text: I apologize, Your Honor, if I was not clear.

context.speaker: Bridget C. Asay
context.text: As a factual matter, we know absolutely that the pharmacies do not sell it to researchers.

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: First, that the privacy interest in it I think is not very significant, because it's how the doctor runs his or her business, and second it would still allow the discrimination.

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: If you were convinced in your hypothetical that what Vermont was trying to do is what it said it was doing here in its findings, and that is, to make it harder for the drug companies to reach the audience and make it easier for the insurance company and the government to reach their audience, Greater New Orleans Broadcasting, which involves a ban on private casino speech but not tribal and governmental speech, says discriminating against speakers like that is very troubling.

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: So that's I think how your hypothetical--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what you're saying I think to Justice Kennedy is answering my earlier question by saying the State cannot constitutionally stop the spread of information.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So if the State said to the pharmacy, all you can do is fill the prescription, that's what doctors think pharmacies are doing, and that's all you can do, you're saying that's unconstitutional?

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: --I am saying that that's unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --that he may not want known, how would you -- how would you write this statute?

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: You would take Justice Kennedy's hypothetical, and I don't think the Court has to confront whether such a statute would be constitutional because it would be very different.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Would you remind me what Justice Kennedy said?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Thomas C. Goldstein
context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The States' argument, however, is contrary to basic First Amendment principles.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The Government may not strive to keep its citizens in the dark so that they will make decisions the State prefers.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Breyer has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Ginsburg and Kagan joined.

context.speaker: Kevin K. Russell
context.text: But if this Court were to, you know, section -- the provision that we are talking about here applies to land use as well as to institutionalized persons, and one would ordinarily think that the statute would have the same meaning depending on context.

context.speaker: Kevin K. Russell
context.text: I recognize that the State's basic argument is that the meaning changes depending on who the defendant is, and I suppose if you accept that it could also depend on -- on what provision is being applied.

context.speaker: Kevin K. Russell
context.text: But that's not normally how statutes work.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But the answer to Justice Alito's question is that in the land use area, zoning for example, those are mostly cases against municipalities or counties?

context.speaker: Kevin K. Russell
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Not against the State.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But those cases did not involve States, right?

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: Those cases did not involve States, that's true.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: But--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And I think that the -- the core question here is the State -- and Justice Alito just posed it: the State is being treated with less dignity than the Federal Government, because your position is that the Federal Government is shielded by its sovereign immunity, and you say the State is not.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: --On the contrary, as to the dignity point, Your Honor, if -- the State voluntarily waives its immunity when it accepts Federal funds that clearly condition the acceptance of the funds on the waiver of its immunity.

context.speaker: Sarah Harrington
context.text: The State in this case doesn't contest that it has waived its sovereign immunity voluntarily to some universe of suits to enforce RLUIPA--

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: And an opinion filed with the clerk today, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals. And accepting federal funding, Texas did not consent to waive its sovereign immunity to suits for money damages under the Act.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Our precedents require that waivers of sovereign immunity be unequivocally expressed in the text of the relevant statute and strictly construed in favor of the sovereign.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The Act's authorization of appropriate relief against a Government is not being equivocal expressed -- unequivocal expression of state consent to monetary claims that our precedents require, nor does Section 1003 of the Rehabilitation Act Amendments of 1986, independently put the State on notice that it could be sued for the damages under the Act.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Breyer joins.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: And an opinion filed with the clerk today, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals. And accepting federal funding, Texas did not consent to waive its sovereign immunity to suits for money damages under the Act.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Our precedents require that waivers of sovereign immunity be unequivocally expressed in the text of the relevant statute and strictly construed in favor of the sovereign.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The Act's authorization of appropriate relief against a Government is not being equivocal expressed -- unequivocal expression of state consent to monetary claims that our precedents require, nor does Section 1003 of the Rehabilitation Act Amendments of 1986, independently put the State on notice that it could be sued for the damages under the Act.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Breyer joins.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Our precedents require that waivers of sovereign immunity be unequivocally expressed in the text of the relevant statute and strictly construed in favor of the sovereign.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The Act's authorization of appropriate relief against a Government is not being equivocal expressed -- unequivocal expression of state consent to monetary claims that our precedents require, nor does Section 1003 of the Rehabilitation Act Amendments of 1986, independently put the State on notice that it could be sued for the damages under the Act.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Breyer joins.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: And that in fact reflects what happened in this case, which is that the jury found that there was a violation -- found that the -- the motivations involved here included an improper motivation, rejected the 4311(c)(1) defense, but then found the violation wasn't willful.

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: So I think, given the structure of the statute, the play here, the ability to adjust to those circumstances, is in the remedy provision, not in the mandatory language of the 4311(c)(1).

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Isn't that -- the government's formulation that the discrimination has to play a substantial role in the termination a limiting principle?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I mean, you answered or appeared to be answering Justice Alito that in a 10-year history if one report of discrimination existed that that would shift the burden to the employer.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Is that an accurate statement of law?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That one report has to play a role that is more than a mere existence, doesn't it?

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: When Congress then wrote the 1991 Civil Rights Act, from which this language derives, amending Title VII they used the Brennan language, "a motivating factor".

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: They didn't use "substantial" and I think that was clearly deliberate.

context.speaker: Eric Schnapper
context.text: Anyone who read Price Waterhouse -- and that provision was written about Price Waterhouse -- would have understood that that was a difference within the Court and they made that choice.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Schnapper, I guess this goes back to Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I find it difficult to grasp the distinction that you draw or what is seems could possibly exist between a willful motivating factor and a non-willful motivating factor.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, to say that it's motivating is -- is to say that it's willful, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Roy G. Davis
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Then you can't agree with me, because my question was why would that be?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You have two people, A and B, they are both supervisors; in the one case B fires the employee because he is in the Army, and he says it: Ha, ha, that's why I'm doing it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In the second case he fires the employee because he thought the employee was, in one of Justice Sotomayor's hypotheticals or anyone else, he fires him for a perfectly good reason, but A has lied about it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the reason A lied about it was because she wanted to tell him a lie so B would fire the employee, and her reason is because he's in the Army.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Those two situations, the second seems to me one of 80 -- 80 million situations, fact-related, that could arise, and I don't know why we want a special standard for such a situation.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: There was evidence that Mulally's and Korenchuk's actions were motivated by hostility toward Staub's military obligations, that Mulally's and Korenchuk's actions caused Buck to fire Staub, and that both Mulally and Korenchuk had the specific intent to cause Staub to be dis -- to be dismissed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Whether the variance between the jury instruction in this case and our -- and the rule we announced today was harmless error or should mandate a new trial, it is a matter that the Seventh Circuit may consider in the first instance on remand.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed, and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Alito has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in which Justice Thomas has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Whether the variance between the jury instruction in this case and our -- and the rule we announced today was harmless error or should mandate a new trial, it is a matter that the Seventh Circuit may consider in the first instance on remand.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You're captured by that one.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So the question is: Can you get out of it with later cases?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And you point to Schor to get out of it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And Schor, as I read it, is an all-factors case, that when she talks in the structural part of -- about -- when Justice O'Connor is talking about the non-due process part, the structural part, just what you said, that there isn't a hard-and-fast rule, that there are a bunch of factors that we should look at.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: At least that's how I read it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And you were reading it as a hard-and-fast rule, which means you win.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But a statute however innocent may no more chip away at the authority of the judicial branch then it may eliminate it entirely.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We cannot compromise the integrity of the system of separated powers and the role of the judiciary in that system even with respect to challenges that at first may seem harmless.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We conclude that the bankruptcy court did not have the constitutional authority to enter final judgment on Vickie's counterclaim.That means that we affirm the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit which reversed the award of damages to Vickie.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We will hear argument first this morning in Case 09-11311, Sykes v. United States.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Ginsburg is not on the bench, but will participate in the argument through the transcripts and the tapes.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Marsh.

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Insofar as you're relying on the aggravated offense, the presence of the aggravated offense, I would appreciate an answer to it.

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: Justice Alito--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: In other words, you're saying -- maybe I haven't made myself clear.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Scalia's answer, which you have adopted, is that if you look at (A) by itself, forget about the aggravated offense completely, it doesn't qualify under ACCA, and that's -- that's one argument.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: But your other argument is that (A), the simple offense, doesn't qualify because of the presence of (B).

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: And I'm trying to just see whether that makes sense.

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Yet ACCA defines burglary as a qualifying crime of violence.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: It's measuring risk, not by the elements of that crime, but by something else, by some measure of incidents in which violence might occur.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So how is that different than the government's argument here and the question that Justice Breyer asked you, which was: It is true, potentially there's some forms of fleeing that might not pose a risk of injury, but statistically there's a large number of incidents in which violence follows.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So how is that different than burglary?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's really my question.

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: You draw it -- I'm sorry?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Where do we draw the line?

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: You draw the line--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I think that was what Justice Breyer was trying to ask you earlier, which is: When do we say that, as in burglary, that some risk is more likely to follow than not in a particular type of crime?

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: --The line is defined by the statute: Serious potential risk of physical injury to another.

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: Now, how do you make that determination?

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: There isn't any here because of all the empirical data presented by the government.

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: It relates to vehicular fleeing as if there was one crime of vehicular fleeing, and most of it is -- is calculated based on death or injury, and that of course is not the category that we have here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I suppose that if we agreed with you that whether it is a violent crime depends upon what other prosecutions for fleeing could have been drawn.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If we agree with you that (1)(a) is negligible because there are other bigger ones for which he wasn't charged, we could leave open the question of what -- what happens in a State that has only one crime for fleeing, and we would -- then we would have to confront the question that Justice Sotomayor has asked.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But if we accept your notion that -- where you have a gradation that is adopted by the State, the lowest gradation cannot be determined to have a high percentage of bodily risk, right?

context.speaker: William E. Marsh
context.text: Yes, that's correct, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: Now, whether in a Begay-type sense you might have some recidivism enhancement under State law that would get you there, I don't know.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: But I -- again, I haven't seen any case that involved that.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Am I right?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: When you replied to Justice Scalia, I thought that he had said that we were dealing with a statute, and you seemed to agree, that said it is a crime to flee a policeman after being ordered to stop.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But I thought we were dealing with a statute that says it is a crime to flee a policeman after being ordered to stop, in a vehicle.

context.speaker: Jeffrey B. Wall
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: However, he drives, the criminal attempting to elude capture, creates the possibility that the police will, in a legitimate and lawful manner, accelerate or use force to bring him within their custody.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Although not dispositive, statistics confirm this commonsense conclusion, for instance, personal injury rates for arson and burglary are about 20% lower than they are for vehicle flight.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

Talk America, Inc. v. Michigan Bell Tele.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Talk America, Inc. v. Michigan Bell Tele.case_name: Talk America, Inc. v. Michigan Bell Telephone Co.
Talk America, Inc. v. Michigan Bell Tele.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 30, 2011

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: That's--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, underlying that question is an issue that I think Justices Ginsburg and Scalia were asking.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Technically feasible is different from economically ridiculous or economically burdensome.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: How does that, "economically burdensome" -- does it get considered by anyone so that -- because one could imagine, as Justice Breyer said, that a competitor could come in and say, now build me the Taj Mahal as an entrance facility or as an interconnection facility.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So is there anyone controlling for that latter issue?

context.speaker: Eric D. Miller
context.text: --In terms of the definition of technical feasibility, that's a defined term in section 51.5 of the regulations, and it does not include economic considerations.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: The FCC argues that an incumbent must lease existing entrance facilities to competitors at cost-based rates if the facilities are to be used for interconnection.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Roberts.

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: Section 3582(a) prohibits courts from imposing or lengthening a term of imprisonment to promote a defendant's rehabilitation, including by facilitating her access to a prison drug treatment program.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Roberts, could I take you back to Justice Kennedy's question at the start about the one-way ratchet?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: What's the government's theory about what Congress might have been thinking when it said you can't think about rehabilitation to sentence or to lengthen a sentence, but you can think about rehabilitation to make a decision not to sentence or to shorten a sentence?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: What would -- what would have been in Congress's mind?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Prisons have multiple treatment programs.

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And they have vocational treatment.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Do you -- are you relying at all on the fact that in the supervised release term, the judge can say this man or this woman needs rehabilitation, and I want this program for her, but in the prison setting, the judge, this judge -- as the colloquy with Justice Scalia showed, this judge wanted her to be in the program, but she never got into it because the judge has no control?

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: Exactly, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: The -- under the SRA, judges have no authority to place prisoners in -- place defendants in prison treatment programs or to require their participation in those programs.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why has he been prevented from doing that, although he's allowed to do it during supervised release?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Does that make any sense, if indeed, as you say, he can take that into account in imprisonment?

context.speaker: Stephanos Bibas
context.text: Your Honor, judges in supervised release, it -- it -- it's hard to understand why in 3583(e)(3) judges may consider rehabilitation in deciding whether to impose a term of imprisonment on resentencing, and we've been offered no logical explanation as to why that same logic Congress would have meant a flat ban here that it didn't spell out in an initial sentencing.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It -- it does seem to me that the principal trouble I have with your argument is that, as Justice Scalia mentioned, the judge can't be certain that the treatment will -- will be provided.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And in an answer to an earlier question you said, well, 90 percent of the time the judge's recommendation is followed, the program is -- is offered.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose we're only 10 percent of the time?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: If so, the sentence would conflict with the Sentencing Reform Act.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: We therefore reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: The opinion of the Court is unanimous.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Alito joins.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: If so, the sentence would conflict with the Sentencing Reform Act.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Can we go back to -- first, you agree that it is unlawful to retaliate against a person who filed a complaint under Title VII by dismissing a close relative?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It is an unlawful employment practice, is it not?

context.speaker: Leigh Gross Latherow
context.text: I believe it could meet the standard under Burlington, yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Do you want to get back to Justice Breyer's question?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I don't think you had a chance to respond to it.

context.speaker: Leigh Gross Latherow
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That is the problem with my theory.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Leigh Gross Latherow
context.text: I'm glad--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But there are -- I do -- I think that it isn't so hard to find in some of the sources that Justice Ginsburg mentioned and others instances where the only kinds of suits that have been allowed are where it was like a family member or was being used as a means, and there never have been cases where they allowed somebody who was just suffering consequent injury.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So it's quite possible I can be borne out, though I think your criticism is a pretty good one.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: --The owner of the car.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: And I believe in Respondent's brief they indicated that -- that some of the police computers will even show descriptive features or maybe even a picture of the driver.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: But in this case Mr. Tolentino was not the registered owner of the vehicle, so that wouldn't have provided them with cause to pull the car over.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This -- this goes back to a question Justice Alito asked in a probably more artful way, but I'm not quite sure what's supposed to happen under your view after this stop.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They stop the person, they get the information that he's driving under a suspended license, and are they supposed to say, Oh, you know, we shouldn't have stopped you; I'm sorry, have a nice day, go ahead, and then he leaves?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is that what goes on?

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: It's just making sure that the Petitioner can't get back in the car and continue driving.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: In order to get the vehicle back, at least in New York State, the -- if it was the Petitioner's, they would have to show proof that they had a valid license; and if it wasn't his vehicle, then the other -- the true owner would have to get -- provide proper credentials to establish that they could take the -- the vehicle into their possession; and also they would have to have proof that the Petitioner himself had cleared up his record or get some sort of a -- a release from the court or from the district attorney's office.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: So the whole purpose of that impoundment statute is for public safety.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I don't understand the answer you gave to Justice Alito.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Maybe I mixed it up.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The police stop the car without cause.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: But the scenario that you are talking about would be highly unlikely, and it would be almost in bad faith if the police stopped him illegally, found out that he had the suspended license, and then let him get back in right away.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: That wouldn't be the way that the police would normally do that, unless there was a way to properly maintain the safety of the road--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: How much time do they have to wait?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Kagan brought up if the police go to his home the next day.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You've brought up attenuation theory a number of times.

context.speaker: Kristina Schwarz
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Caitlin J. Halligan
context.text: Because it has a unique status, as this Court recognized in Hiibel, in the criminal justice system.

context.speaker: Caitlin J. Halligan
context.text: Asking for a name is a routine and accepted part of any stop because the officer needs to know who he's dealing with.

context.speaker: Caitlin J. Halligan
context.text: He faces an inordinate risk, as this Court noted in Mimms and most recently in Arizona v. Gant, of being shot when he approaches a car.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What's the difference between stopping a car and stopping a person on the street, as Justice Sotomayor asked?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You can't stop somebody on the street for no reason.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The person looks to you suspicious, so you stop the person and say: Tell me your name.

context.speaker: Caitlin J. Halligan
context.text: --You could resolve the case on the theory that by definition government records that are previously held--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But they're only inevitably discovered if he makes a mistake of saying what his name is.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No, no, not that -- the mistake of saying: I was driving the car.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And then, as Justice Scalia pointed out, maybe you could suppress that, so it would -- it would--

context.speaker: Caitlin J. Halligan
context.text: --In this case the question of any observations of the defendant is waived.

context.speaker: Caitlin J. Halligan
context.text: It was abandoned by operation of State law.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Or are you making a broader claim that anytime someone is subject to incarceration they must have counsel?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: It is definitely the broader claim; that is, this -- this decision about counsel has to be determined ex ante, because the State -- and this is our limit -- I suppose our more limited request for a categorical rule.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Where you have a State that has placed the burden on the noncustodial parent--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, my -- my question follows from what I think Justice Ginsburg must have in mind.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: My understanding is that it's a commonplace if the witness declines to testify even though the witness has immunity, or the attorney or the witness declines to produce a document, the judge says you will remain in jail until you comply.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In most of the States I think he's allowed counsel; but does the broad statement that you -- or the broad argument that you responded, that you're making when you answered Justice Ginsburg's case, apply there, so we are in effect saying in all these cases you must have appointed counsel?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Where you have a State that has placed the burden on the noncustodial parent--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, my -- my question follows from what I think Justice Ginsburg must have in mind.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: My understanding is that it's a commonplace if the witness declines to testify even though the witness has immunity, or the attorney or the witness declines to produce a document, the judge says you will remain in jail until you comply.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In most of the States I think he's allowed counsel; but does the broad statement that you -- or the broad argument that you responded, that you're making when you answered Justice Ginsburg's case, apply there, so we are in effect saying in all these cases you must have appointed counsel?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --No, no, no.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Our submission is any case in which the State proposes to deprive somebody with an unqualified right to liberty of that liberty by actual incarceration, there is a right to counsel.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --I'm sorry -- and because it is a civil proceeding--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It's an illogical distinction is what I'm saying.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --Well--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Maybe Justice Alito can--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: MR. WAXMAN -- I'm not sure, but--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --can ask his question.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: And what the court -- and recognizing that Lassiter is dicta, because it did consider that context, what it said is we have to -- we have to do the Matthews v. Eldridge balancing against a generalization, a preeminent generalization that exists in our case law, which is that there is a presumption that an indigent defendant has a right to appointed counsel only when he loses or may be deprived of his liberties.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Since that doesn't apply here, we have to do the Matthews v. Eldridge balancing against the presumption that cuts the other way.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --My concern is -- and it's been brought up in some of the other questions that Justice Ginsburg asked earlier -- I just have the sense that there are thousands of these hearings around the country, and they're -- and they're very important in order to ensure child support, and that if we adopt your rule, in many cases where counsel are now waived or not present because of the -- the noncompliant parent is going to ask for counsel and that we're going to change the entire landscape of domestic relations proceeding, the Heisenberg principle.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Justice Kennedy, the vast majority of jurisdictions require counsel and provide counsel, and there is no -- we would think if this were--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In every case?

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You say alternate procedures can provide people in this situation with a fair shake.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: But then when you look at the procedures that you actually say would comply with due process, they are remarkably anemic.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Basically, you say that a form has to be provided.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You don't require that there be anybody attached to the court, the kind of person that Justice Powell might have been talking about in Vitek, some kind of caseworker to assist the person with whatever questions he might have about the form or about how to fill it out.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You don't require that the court make any findings.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: You don't require that the court even ask any questions.

context.speaker: Leondra R. Kruger
context.text: Where in other jurisdictions the law is clear that the other information may be relevant to that inquiry, it would be appropriate for the form to elicit that information as well.

context.speaker: Leondra R. Kruger
context.text: But I think in substance the form would look very much like the form that this Court sees on a regular basis attached to its petitions for writs of certiorari, and would also look very much like forms that are commonly applied in jurisdictions across the country in child support programs in order to establish the amounts of child support obligation in the first place.

context.speaker: Leondra R. Kruger
context.text: South Carolina employs such a form for that purpose, and I think it would be a relatively trivial matter for South Carolina to use a similar form for the purpose of enforcement.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Ms. Kruger, could you say a bit more about the question that Mr. Waxman and Justice Scalia were talking about: how often these proceedings have the State on one side, how often they have the custodial parent on one side, whether there is counsel for the opposite side in many of these cases?

context.speaker: Leondra R. Kruger
context.text: There is in some, but not all, Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Leondra R. Kruger
context.text: It's true that the State is often, though not always represented in these proceedings, not always by lawyers as opposed to caseworkers or other nonlawyer personnel who work for the departments of social services.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Here, South Carolina provided neither counsel nor alternative procedures.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thus, Turner's proceedings were constitutionally defective.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We vacate the judgment of the South Carolina Supreme Court and we remand the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting Opinion in which Justice Scalia joins and in which the Chief Justice and Justice Alito join as to Parts I-B and II.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Here, South Carolina provided neither counsel nor alternative procedures.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thus, Turner's proceedings were constitutionally defective.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We vacate the judgment of the South Carolina Supreme Court and we remand the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting Opinion in which Justice Scalia joins and in which the Chief Justice and Justice Alito join as to Parts I-B and II.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Here, South Carolina provided neither counsel nor alternative procedures.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Thus, Turner's proceedings were constitutionally defective.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We vacate the judgment of the South Carolina Supreme Court and we remand the case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting Opinion in which Justice Scalia joins and in which the Chief Justice and Justice Alito join as to Parts I-B and II.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What's the argument against doing that?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why can't we?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm sure there's some rule out there that says we can't do this, but I want to know what it is because it seems fair.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --May I suggest that perhaps the reason not to do it is, assuming this person was treated entirely fairly on the basis of the law that existed at the time, the consequence of what Justice Breyer proposes is to set free someone who has been duly convicted of a crime.

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And to do that simply because, although the -- the process was perfectly fair when it was applied, there's been a change in the rule and therefore we don't redo it, but we let this person go; right?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Any other reason?

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: I agree completely, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Matthew D. Roberts
context.text: While, I think--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, I'm thinking that we normally -- although all this is quite true, what Justice Scalia says, normally we do apply new rules to those who are on appeal at the time.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't -- I don't agree with that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Do you agree with that?

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: We think this is a straightforward case where the text dictates the outcome of the case.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: Remember, the key words in the statute are "delay resulting from", and I think the -- I think the ordinary meaning, in fact, the only meaning, of "delay" is a hindrance to progress or a postponement.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: So it's--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry to interrupt you so early, but what about Justice Ginsburg's point, which I understood to be there's always delay resulting from these pretrial motions; it's just that the district judge takes that into account, says, well, I'm going to have a lot of the usual pretrial motions, so I'm going to set the trial date at this point.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So that is delay, when the trial date might otherwise have been set, resulting from these pretrial motions, and then the -- the statute goes on to tell you how you count that delay.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: --That's exactly our argument, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: So--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It matters because the trial judges have to know what to do, and while your reading might fit the language in ordinary English better, I think it does.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's also possible to read those words "delay resulting from" as simply referring to a period of time; and the statute is saying these periods of time are excluded from accounting.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, the virtue of that is just what Justice Ginsburg started with; all the trial judges know how to do it; the lawyers don't get mixed up; and the problem with what you're arguing for, in my mind -- if you want to say anything more about it, do -- is that it seems very unworkable to strike trying to figure out what causes what.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: --Let me say a couple things, Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Jeffrey L. Fisher
context.text: First, with all due respect, I have to disagree with your premise that it's possible to read the statute the way the Solicitor General wants to read it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We explain all these more thoroughly in our opinion.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: As I said, we disagree with two separate aspects of what the Court of Appeals decided, that those two determinations that we find erroneous in a sense, cancel each other out.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And we consequently affirm the Court of Appeals ultimate finding of the Speedy Trial Act violation.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment in which the Chief Justice and Justice Thomas have joined.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We explain all these more thoroughly in our opinion.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: As I said, we disagree with two separate aspects of what the Court of Appeals decided, that those two determinations that we find erroneous in a sense, cancel each other out.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And we consequently affirm the Court of Appeals ultimate finding of the Speedy Trial Act violation.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment in which the Chief Justice and Justice Thomas have joined.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: As I said, we disagree with two separate aspects of what the Court of Appeals decided, that those two determinations that we find erroneous in a sense, cancel each other out.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And we consequently affirm the Court of Appeals ultimate finding of the Speedy Trial Act violation.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment in which the Chief Justice and Justice Thomas have joined.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation.speaker: Justice Alito
United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation.case_name: United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation
United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 20, 2011

context.speaker: Pratik A. Shah
context.text: It is paying for the legal advice out of congressional appropriations.

context.speaker: Pratik A. Shah
context.text: The government owns the records at issue by virtue of the Federal Records Act, by virtue of Interior Department regulations, which are cited in the back of our brief make very clear that the government owns these records, and because they are governmental records their disclosure is not governed by the common law.

context.speaker: Pratik A. Shah
context.text: There is a highly--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The thrust of what -- my understanding of the thrust of what Justice Sotomayor was asking is something like the following: It's easy to understand how there can be competing government interests when you're talking about some, the management of lands, things of that nature.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: But when you're just talking about managing funds, what competing interests can there be in practical terms?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: If you assume arguendo that this exception applies to a private trustee, why should it not apply to the government in practical terms?

United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation.speaker: Justice Alito
United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation.case_name: United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation
United States v. Jicarilla Apache Nation.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 13, 2011

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: In this case, the relevant statute delineates specific disclosure obligations of the Government to the Tribe.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Common law does not override the specific trust-creating statute and regulations that apply here.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Ginsburg has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in which Justice Breyer has joined.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.case_name: United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: These are quite different things.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: And even in -- it's not--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But you couldn't get both.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, that's I think Justice Sotomayor's point, about duplication.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It's not -- even if you can say, yes, it's a different mode of relief, but you could -- couldn't get -- I mean, suppose we didn't have 1500 and you prevailed in your suit on the APCA or whatever you call the statute.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: You could not then turn around and sue the government official, because you have the -- the single claim, you've been compensated.

United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.speaker: Justice Roberts
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.case_name: United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: It applies to any claim for and in respect to which any suit or process is pending in any other court against the U.S. or any person acting or professing to act as its agents.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: It's a very broad statute.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It's not -- I mean, you are putting a pejorative spin on what they are doing, saying, you know, many plaintiffs like to take a chance in more than one court.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But your response to Justice Breyer suggests that that's a tough choice if you have to choose between injunctive relief or damages.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: That's not them trying to, you know, get the same -- take two bites at the apple.

context.speaker: Anthony A. Yang
context.text: In some cases, it's is a tough choice.

United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.speaker: Justice Breyer
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.case_name: United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Danielle Spinelli
context.text: And that turns not on whether the district court has jurisdiction, but on whether duplicative relief is sought in both suits.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The main thrust that I was raising was does this really get the Tribe into trouble?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They have to forego one kind of relief for another.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So what about injunctive relief, that's what he thought of, and Justice Scalia raises the point, well, they are not going to be entitled to injunctive relief anyway because the APA doesn't provide it, if I understand that correctly.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So you are giving up the null set.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You were giving up the null set.

United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.speaker: Justice Kennedy
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.case_name: United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Danielle Spinelli
context.text: And the Nation is entitled to both sums of money, but they are different, and because the money sought in the two courts is different, the relief is not duplicative.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: My problem is that I read the CFC complaint as including both.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I will take a look at it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I intruded on Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What I'm trying to work out still in my mind, is if you say, look, Indian Tribe: You have to go to the court of claims, period.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Period.

United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.speaker: Justice Breyer
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.case_name: United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Well, if the amount differs, then, why do you suppose the cotton belonged to the Indian Tribe?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: On the one hand, they want an accounting out of the money ever earned out of this cotton in the past and on the other hand, they want what the cotton is worth in the future on the--

context.speaker: Danielle Spinelli
context.text: That is not--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --That's Justice Scalia's question.

context.speaker: Danielle Spinelli
context.text: --That is not duplicative.

context.speaker: Danielle Spinelli
context.text: What is duplicative is a remedy that is either the same, or a remedy that serves as a substitute for another remedy.

United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.speaker: Justice Kennedy
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.case_name: United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation
United States v. Tohono O'odham Nation.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 26, 2011

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Hence, the statute bars jurisdiction in the Court of Federal Claims, when the plaintiff has a suit based on substantially the same operative facts, it's pending elsewhere and here, the Nation's two suits involve almost identical operative facts, they relate to the same trust assets, and they describe almost identical alleged breaches of fiduciary duty.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The Court of Federal Appeals' action -- the Court of Federal Claims' action must therefore be dismissed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The contrary judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit is reversed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment, in which Justice Breyer joins.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Ginsburg has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in consideration or decision of the case.
