Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Does it ever do anything else other than administer the Federal program?

context.speaker: Seth M. Galanter
context.text: It has a few responsibilities that the State has given it under State law in addition, but its primary function -- and at this point all its budget comes from the Federal Government, and it serves primarily this Federal function to go into public and private institutions to observe and make sure that abuse and neglect is not occurring there.

context.speaker: Seth M. Galanter
context.text: And that is obviously why these records were requested, because the statute gives the protection and advocacy service a right to access records of people in the institution to make sure that they are not being mistreated and that investigations and the oversights by the State are taking place and are being done correctly.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Counsel, following up on Justice Scalia's question to you, his question in fact is in part what happened here.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Virginia at some point did require every State agency to seek the permission of its attorney general, is it, to sue?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And the government said that's not independent enough, and if you want the money you've got to make VOPA eligible to sue without that permission; is that correct?

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: They weren't subject to removal by the same head of government.

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: So I think, while you might have an Article 3 problem in some situations, you don't have that problem here because of VOPA's independence.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Could you be a little bit more specific for me on what you mean about an Article 3 problem?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Justice Kennedy was concerned about State attorney generals willy-nilly suing -- or not willy-nilly, suing governors to comply with Federal law.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Why do you think it won't happen, and what are the legal impediments to that occurring?

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: I think there are several.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: --Well, under Virginia law I think that VOPA's officials are subject to for-cause removal provisions.

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: So they can actually be removed judicially through for-cause proceedings.

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: And from our perspective that is consistent with VOPA's independence and it's full authority to pursue remedies because that type of for-cause removal wouldn't be on the basis of VOPA's actions in litigation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Going back to your exchange with Justice Breyer, I assume that you could stand by your answer and say the attorney general could sue the governor, because he's not suing the governor in his official capacity.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He has a Federal right under Ex parte Young to sue the governor as an individual.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's a fiction, we all know that.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Breyer
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: Well, I think that you might have State sovereignty interests at that point.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's your position.

context.speaker: Ginger D. Anders
context.text: That would prevent a Federal court from adjudicating a suit, but there's no question that those interests aren't present here because Virginia has chosen to create a State agency in order to enforce these Federal rights.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm with Justice Scalia on this.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I will pass to the other side.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Thank you, Ms. Anderson.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Breyer
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Earle Duncan Getchell Jr
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: Earle Duncan Getchell Jr
context.text: Congress should have expected, in the hypothetical Congress was posited as having thought--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The hypothetical -- Justice Sotomayor is totally right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I am talking about Ex parte Young.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I am imagining.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Breyer
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 01, 2010

context.speaker: Earle Duncan Getchell Jr
context.text: I think it's all that is really appropriately before this Court, because again, we are up here on an interlocutory appeal where the decision below in the Fourth Circuit by Judge Wilkinson is premised entirely on sovereign immunity.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, explain to me -- this is good, because that's very helpful to me.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's the exact statement that Justice Scalia made, and you said, Yes, that's exactly right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And then it is the case of that a citizen of the State can come into the Federal court and sue the State official under Ex parte Young, but you say, but the agency of the State can't do it, even though they have State litigating authority.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the reason that the latter is more injurious of the dignity interests of the State than the former is--

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Scalia
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The likely explanation is that state agencies do not often possess federal rights against their parent states and they cannot sue to enforce those rights unless the parent states consent to give them independent litigating authority.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We are unaware that these conditions have ever presented themselves except in connection with the unusual federal statute at issue here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: For this and other reasons set forth more fully in our opinion, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case before the proceeding is consistent with our opinion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Thomas has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a descending opinion in which Justice Alito has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Scalia
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The likely explanation is that state agencies do not often possess federal rights against their parent states and they cannot sue to enforce those rights unless the parent states consent to give them independent litigating authority.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We are unaware that these conditions have ever presented themselves except in connection with the unusual federal statute at issue here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: For this and other reasons set forth more fully in our opinion, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case before the proceeding is consistent with our opinion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Thomas has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a descending opinion in which Justice Alito has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Scalia
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We are unaware that these conditions have ever presented themselves except in connection with the unusual federal statute at issue here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: For this and other reasons set forth more fully in our opinion, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case before the proceeding is consistent with our opinion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Thomas has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a descending opinion in which Justice Alito has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.speaker: Justice Scalia
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.case_name: Virginia Office for Protection and Advocacy v. Stewart
Virginia Office for Protection and Advoc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 19, 2011

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: For this and other reasons set forth more fully in our opinion, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case before the proceeding is consistent with our opinion.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion in which Justice Thomas has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a descending opinion in which Justice Alito has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose there's no deliberate indifference and a specific policy prohibiting the discrimination, can you still proceed?

context.speaker: Joseph M. Sellers
context.text: --I -- well, I would submit you still can proceed.

context.speaker: Joseph M. Sellers
context.text: If -- if the policy -- announcing a policy saying don't discriminate were to be effective in -- in immunizing companies against liability in class actions, imagine every company in the country would publish that policy and have free license to go discriminate as much as it wanted to.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: I understand your answer to Justice Kennedy's question to be that this typical company would be in violation of Title VII; is that correct?

context.speaker: Joseph M. Sellers
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: That's what the -- and that's what the academic literature on which your theory is based includes; isn't that right?

context.speaker: Joseph M. Sellers
context.text: Well, Justice Scalia, I -- I -- I want to deal with the -- in this instance, we have -- it's not just any old analysis that we're -- that we're using.

context.speaker: Joseph M. Sellers
context.text: We have statistical regression analysis that isolates and takes into account the factors such as performance and -- and seniority.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: See, I wasn't talking about this case.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I was talking about your answer to Justice Alito--

context.speaker: Joseph M. Sellers
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --which said that, you know, it may well be that every industry in the United States is guilty of sex discrimination--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Rules Enabling Act forbids interpreting the federal rules to "abridge, enlarge or modify any substantive right" including Wal-Mart's statutory defenses.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Wal-Mart is in entitled to litigate those defenses and the necessity of that litigation demonstrates that respondents' backpay claims are not incidental.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: For these and other reasons set forth more fully in our opinion, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Ginsburg has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part in which Justices Breyer, Sotomayor and Kagan have joined.

context.speaker: Todd Marshall
context.text: Mr. Martin went through a full round of superior court, court of appeal, and supreme court challenges, and then waited some additional years and has never explained why he didn't include these additional claims in those earlier challenges.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So you think it--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's supposed to be filed within 60 days.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I don't -- this is along the same lines as Justice Kagan's questions.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose there's the first round of habeas and then he waits 60 days and files the new claim.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Would that be substantial?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Well, why would it be different in the capital context?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What was the reason for adding the 90 days there?

context.speaker: Todd Marshall
context.text: Capital cases are significantly more complex, the punishments are -- are more significant, and so additional scrutiny might be warranted in those contexts.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --I'm a little bit confused by your response to Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I thought from your brief that you were positing that there was no claim of inconsistent application of the rule that could ever survive.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Let's assume for the sake of argument the following hypothetical, and probably not far off the mark.

context.speaker: Todd Marshall
context.text: --Yes, exactly.

context.speaker: Todd Marshall
context.text: No one--

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: I don't understand your answer, then.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: You have -- let me just adapt what Justice Sotomayor said.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: You have -- a case, a Supreme Court case is decided.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: And you have ten -- ten habeas petitioners in California who file on exactly the same day.

context.speaker: Michael R Bigelow
context.text: Now, and that's the interesting thing about California.

context.speaker: Michael R Bigelow
context.text: We are presuming, we are presuming and this Court has reached that presumption, that they are merit denials when they are silent, but we really don't know.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's a puzzle to me.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, Justice Scalia's question was courts all the time, they all the time, they don't decide an issue of whether it's filed too late because it's the simplest thing just to decide the merits.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's the same result.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And sometimes they don't do that.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Would Rule 35 permit a challenge for a Federal violation?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You have given an example of an illegal sentence that you think is discretionary; am I correct?

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: --Not--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But does Rule 35(a) permit a legal challenge of the kind that Justice Kagan was asking?

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: --Correct.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: Our Rule 35 contains within the same provision a challenge to the legality of the sentence, to the manner in which it was imposed--

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: It's not much different at all, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: It's essentially the same.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: It is simply--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But that's bad for you, isn't it, for the very point that Justice Kennedy was raising?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: If it's the same sort of arguments that you get to raise as a legal matter prior to the imposition of sentencing, why should they not be considered legal matters when they are raised under Rule 35?

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: --Because we don't believe they are legal matters, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: What the--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That is the standard of review.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So please explain to me why that is not what Justice Kennedy described as a review for abuse of discretion and why a review for abuse of discretion is not a legal challenge?

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: Well, what we suggest is the abuse of discretion that that is talking about is if there is no justification.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: Again, they look at the sentence and if there is no justification for it then it will be an abuse of discretion.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: If he had put in that word "illegal", would that have made the difference?

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: It might, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: And under our system it might -- that might have been characterized, not as a sentence reduction provision or sentence reduction vehicle, but as a legal motion to correct an illegal sentence, or challenging the sentence.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So but that does suggest the difficulty that Justice Scalia raises, is that we are going to have to look at the particular rule of the State, we are going to have to look at the particular motion, we are going to look at any -- we're going to have to look at any State law regarding how motions are construed.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: And this is going to be a very difficult determination.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: They have 120 days.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: It can be filed after the sentence is imposed, 120 days of that date, or 120 days after the conviction becomes final.

context.speaker: Aaron L. Weisman
context.text: We would suggest that the term "collateral review" embraces, as Justice Alito indicated, sort of that concept that obviously in a tolling provision it begins to run when the conviction becomes final.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Scalia's suggestion--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Except that it says--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --that perhaps the -- the leniency review is -- is not review of the conviction or sentence.

context.speaker: Judith H. Mizner
context.text: Rule 35 is a collateral proceeding.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: That's -- just so your adversary, when he gets up on rebuttal can confirm or not this point, any challenge to an illegal sentence has to be brought first with a Rule 35(a) a motion, regardless of what the grounds of illegality are?

context.speaker: Judith H. Mizner
context.text: Yes, or perhaps in a motion for post-conviction relief under section 10-9.1.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Can I return to the question Justice Ginsburg asked a couple minutes ago?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Let's say we have a case in which a defendant convicted in State court has some exhausted Federal claims that this defendant wants to raise in a Federal habeas; also files a motion seeking a reduction of sentence based purely on a request for leniency, sentence within the range prescribed by the statute.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: What purpose is served by tolling the time to file the Federal habeas during the pendency of this request for leniency in the State court?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: For the reason stated in the opinion filed today, we hold that the phrase "collateral review" in this provision means judicial review of a judgment in a proceeding that is not part of the direct review process.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The parties here agree that Rhode Island's motion to reduce sentence is not part of the direct review process, so we hold that it is an application for a collateral review that tolls the limitation period.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We therefore affirm the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part.

Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.case_name: Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, Inc.
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Garre--

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: The agency preserved that very status quo in 1989.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Petitioners recognize that in note 1 of their brief.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Mr. Garre, in -- in Geier I think it was Justice Breyer who called attention to the agency having informed the Court that if tort suits were to go on, at -- in -- in contradiction to the government's view that there should be both of these -- that the safety standards that were set there, it would be disturbed.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It would be impeded.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And the opinion said we assign weight to the Department of Transportation there, to their view that a tort suit there would stand as an obstacle to the accomplishment of the Federal safety standards.

Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.speaker: Justice Roberts
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.case_name: Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, Inc.
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: --Justice Sotomayor, there are hundreds of Federal motor vehicle safety standards, and I would agree with you for virtually all of them, except you have the rare standards -- and they are rare, like the one in Geier and like the one here -- where the agency quite obviously is doing something much different.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: It's expressly granting options and it's making clear in the record that the reason it is doing that is to serve Federal objectives that would be frustrated by the imposition of a particular rule.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: I think you have to look at this from the standpoint of the manufacturers who are told that they can manufacture this car with this design or that design, and you can go look at the Federal Register and see that the reason the agency is doing that is to advance safety and practicability objectives.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: How do you tell -- in response to Justice Sotomayor, how do you tell whether the agency is giving options or simply setting a minimum?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, first you would look--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Because a minimum, of course, always gives you options.

Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.speaker: Justice Breyer
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.case_name: Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, Inc.
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 03, 2010

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: First, as the language you just read indicates, it didn't require -- they didn't encourage at all costs.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: They encouraged where this specific safety concern could be addressed.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Second, there is a world of difference between saying, we encourage manufacturers to do what's appropriate when they can practically do so, and a world in which a jury could have decided the day after--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Those arguments are what I think Justice Sotomayor was saying: It is a huge problem for manufacturers.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's called tort suits in different places and different juries and different States.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But that is beyond the scope of this case.

Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.speaker: Justice Breyer
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.case_name: Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, Inc.
Williamson v. Mazda Motor of America, In.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 23, 2011

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The choice wasn't that important.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The state lawsuit is not preempted.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The judgment of the California Court is reversed.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Sotomayor has filed a concurring opinion, Justice Thomas has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment and Justice Kagan took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
